Solid, pioneering bit of horror FPS. The first game I'm aware of to use the FPS 'grab and interact' style of gameplay which later made Amnesia such a firm favourite (this being the predecessor). I just complated it today, and it really does sell atmosphere incredibly well. The graphics are really dated at this point, but it didn't stop the scares coming thick and fast. Lots of really clever twists, and a story that didn't disappoint me at the end. I absolutely recommend this to horror genre fans.

Penumbra: Black Plague  - the beginning of the end. After leaving the abandoned mines, Philip's journey continues as he finds himself imprisoned in the so-called 'The Shelter', being even more determined to find out his father's fate; the circumstances in which he finds himself also play an important role in his decision of pursuing the mysteries behind this desolate location and its downfall.   The pinnacle of this short horror survival series is found in this game where our character not only meets a couple of 'his friends' from the previous game but he also makes some new sentient bipedal 'friends' as he explores the depths of 'The Shelter' in search for answers.  Relevant psychological themes and horror survival combined with interesting and captivating puzzles make this game an exceptional journey with a meaningful and well-made storyline. An unique experience you have to try.

Mechanically, Black Plague improves on Overture by removing combat, making escape and evasion the only tactics when confronted with enemies. This doesn't mean they are any more difficult to deal with, however. They may look substantially more imposing than the first game's dogs, but they behave almost identically, making them very easy to exploit. The other elements of the game are simply more of the same, though that isn't a bad thing. Storywise, Black Plague leaves behind the mines of Overture and throws the player into decrepit laboratories with the added atmospheric touch of significantly more sinisterly splattered blood and ominous corpses. More characters are introduced early on, though while this improves the player engagement this time around, one of them is very talkative and voiced in a manner that is highly incongruous with the setting. Think 'The Darkness'. The tone is a horrible mismatch, and the atmosphere suffers as a result.

This series doesn't look like much on the surface, but if given a fighting chance, it stands up to some of the best horror games on the market and holds its own. It presents a very story-rich experience while keeping the suspense level high enough that you're always at least a little worried about what is going to be behind the next door. Some of the puzzles can be frustrating, but this game is definitely worth your time.

Real horror is a connection with the audience. It taps into our insecurities, plays on our weaknesses. Real horror is scary because, simply put, it feels real.  This game didn't feel that way.   Don't misunderstand; I enjoyed it. There's a lot to love about the title, the least of which is the well-integrated physics systems and the 'realistic' puzzles. Don't expect doors to start opening just because you found a note somewhere. Not that kind of game, which is a relief.   But for all that I felt it was more 'sci-fi romp' (romp... why do critics and reviewers always use that word?) than 'survival horror.' At no point during the game did I actually feel that my life was in danger. The conditions are right. The execution is close to right. So what's lacking here?  I think, in the end, the baddies just aren't imposing enough. They're slow, and forgiving to the point that if you run thirty feet away and turn a corner, they give up on you. That and they run simple patrols. Makes this feel more like a stealth mission than a life-threatening escape scenario.  But do play it, because (before the weird end sequence), the writing is just too phenomenal to miss out on. Seriously. It's weird too see a game where the writing outshines everything else for once. It's like they took someone working on a bestseller and said 'hey, forget the book. Come write journal entries for our game.' Pretty astounding, really.  3.8/5 for me.
Very fun game. Works well with nearly any computer and has an atmosphere that makes you peek anxiously around every little nook and corner.

The second installment of the Penumbra series, Black Plauge ticks all the boxes its predecessor failed to do. Its not without glitches but far less this time around. The save points are more common now and the enemies far less irritating when it comes to moving your character in search for the next clue. The puzzles are once again exceptional and the tone creepy and unsettling like its supposed to be. Would definitely recommend to any Penumbra or horror/mystery/puzzle fan in general.

In my opinion, The Black Plague was even better than the original, Overture. My only problems, though, stemmed from the fact that numerous puzzles were just too hard and frustrating for me. Namely, the dreaded three or four final levels. I basically had to keep a pair of walkthroughs open in the Steam overlay so I could finally finish the game. People who are far smarter than me wouldn't have as much trouble as I did. Other than that, yes, it's a good game. The plot, the premise, the backstory... everything felt much deeper in here than in Overture. There also seemed to be more substance to the enemies here than in Overture, which were just angry, mangy dogs, annoying spiders and big, scary worms, whcih seemed to have little explanation or relevance to the story.   This might be a bit of a spoiler... I noticed that much of what happened here really reminded me of System Shock 2. Hybrids= The Infected. SHODAN/The Many=the thing that is responsible for this whole mess. The Von Braun= The Shelter/Mines. The list goes on.  Anyway, I liked Black Plague a bit more than Overture, though they were both pretty good.  One last note, be careful with the graphics settings, especially screen resolution. I had problems with double images on screen, especially with the player's glowstick. I suspect this stems from the issues with widescreen monitors.
Best of the 3 Penumbra games. Basicly Amnesia with a few weapons and not as nervewrecking.

Really improves upon the previous game: a lot happens story-wise, many things are explained, the traditional puzzles are better (but still easy), the physics-based puzzles are less tedious/annoying and the sneaking parts are not many (so the complete lack of weapons doesn't feel that heavy).  The comic relief provided by your troll antagonist is fine, and the 'inside your mind/slightly disturbing' sequences add a nice touch to the monotony of the mine.  8/10 I really wanted the biggest hug of my life, WHY CLARENCE, WHY!!!???

Otherwise, enjoy art in a fine form.

After the disappointment that was Penumbra Overture, although I acknowledge it was an introduction to Black Plague, this game is indeed what Penumbra is all about. Having played Amnesia before, I believe this game feels fundamentally very similar, such as a parallel game (gameplay and mechanics are exactly the same) and at the same time very different (story, context and purpose).   In this game there is an immediate sense of danger, there is no way to avoid enemies other than outsmart them, thinking fast and finding a solution right when they suddenly appear before you (while scarying the crap out of you). Also, you are CONSTANTLY solving puzzles. There is no way you can progress without solving a puzzle in the current room, every section of the game is a maze and requires going to point A to get item X to go back and open door B. and while you are going back the monsters come in.   The story is where this game falls short. The motivation of this game is finding out what happened to the character's father, it is unknown if he is still alive. While you are at that, you get infected by an intelligent virus that talks to you (annoys you mostly) and can blurry your vision, confuse you, etc. That virus character is so annoying that made me really hate him and wish it was quickly over. Also, from Penumbra Overture I was expecting a different explanation to the existance of all those monsters, and it turned out to be a very different thing.  Still, for horror game fans, it is an interesting experience, not superior to Amnesia, but fun nonetheless.

Takes what was built in Overture and improves on it! Somewhat short, if you don't get stuck on the puzzles, but better in every way. Pretty scary throughout and spectacular ending! Great puzzles (I cite the radio puzzle as the best I've seen in a game) and a lonesome, oppressive atmosphere (the setting is ripe for a horror tale) make this game a must for horror fans. For those unfamiliar with the genre it might be a bit of a dive into the deep end due to the clunky combat and the resultant emphasis on hiding rather than fighting.  The physics engine adds a lot to the game, making it stick out a bit amongst its peers (especially for its time) as you can pick up items and place/throw them as you wish. This is primarily utilized for puzzles and creating obstacles to hide from enemies.  The story doesn't go too far in this entry, mostly setting the scene for the sequel. It's worth experiencing, as it leads to something a bit more profound than what we're used to seeing in most horror titles.

I'm an avid horror game player, and this is a top competitor for my scariest game and definitely takes the cake for my favorite horror game.  The only problems I ran across were technical issues in the beginning. I did need to tweak graphic options a lot but I don't have a gaming pc, and it only needed about 10 minutes of attention to fix. Oh, and it's extremely puzzle based, and I found some of the puzzles can be obnoxious; so don't restrict yourself from using the internet as a source.

'AHHHHHHHH! â¥â¥â¥â¥ YOU â¥â¥â¥â¥ YOU â¥â¥â¥â¥ YOU!!!! AHHH !â¥â¥â¥â¥ *cries*' Hi that was me when i played this game. If you want a game that will scare the â¥â¥â¥â¥ out of you then play this one (and overture first :) ) 10/10 in my book

I am going to say that after SOMA, I hope Frictional tries something new out besides first person horror. It really seems that all these games are exactly the same. If you played Amnesia: The Dark Descent, don't bother playing this, it did not bring anything more to the table. The storyline and gameplay are at odds with one another, the grandiose monologues are empty and unaffective. I never felt anything but emptiness, stress, and dissatifaction the whole way through this game, and not in an aesthetically intriguing way - I just wish I never played this game. Amnesia at least made you feel like you were in hell, this game just made you feel like it was trying to tell you something but you were not sure what it was and just felt annoyed at all of its annoying voiceover and â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ NPCs.

Great follow up to the 1st part (Overture). The puzzles you need to solve (again, like in the 1st part, they are evnvironmental for the most part) are substantially more challenging and there is essentially no combat in this one, rather, you need to truly make use of stealth this time around if you want to survive.   As for the umbilical gibbering manchildren things running around, I just about sh*t myself the first time I saw one (you'll know when the 1st sighting is about to occur as the character you are states that you need to hide, but I wasn't quite expecting what came walking through the door next).  The lab/research facility a majority of this entry takes place in is definitely spooktacular and the graphics and sound are stll in top form (well, maybe not the graphics but the sound for sure).  All in all this was a fun adventure and I can't wait to play the final part (Requiem).  LATER (3/17/14 @ 6:30 PM EST):  Well, I finally played + completed the final part (Requiem) and I have to say it was...interesting. It kinda, sorta gave me the impression that it didn't quite belong in the Penumbra series, like it was a standalone game based, in part, on the 1st two games (Overture and Black Plague), but it was still a good game.   The puzzles were even more complex this time around and entirely environmental in nature; so much so that it should have been called Penumbra: Requiem for a Puzzle Solver. Also, (this is a pseudo SPOILER if you read on and may throw some off from wanting to play the game at all knowing what Overture and Black Plague had to offer) there were no creatures at all save for a vague shadowy form under the water in the sewer area.  Overall, this was probably my least favorite of the 3 parts in this series, but it was still fun and if you find yourself to be a hardcore Penumbra fan after the 1st two parts, then you should definitely give this one a go too!

Dem creeps man!! If you're looking for a good horror game HERE IT IS, it's made my the same comany who made Amnesia, (I liked that one as well) it's got all the heart stopping thrills (mostly getting scared my noises and random things that are not scary like boxes and pips e.e ) and the freaky monsters your looing for. The storry line is awesome and fun to play though, the graphics could be a little better but all in all.... GET THIS GAME IF YOU LIKE HORROR GAMES!!!
I can't say enough good things about this game. It's true survival horror with lots of interesting puzzles. It almost reminds me of some of the earlier Resident Evil games but without the weapons.

Of the Penumbra series, Black Plague was the most thrilling. It left you in suspense sometimes wondering what is actually happening. You spend a lot more time running for your life as well. As recommended for the first of the series (Overture) you will enjoy the game more if you play in the dark and playing the whole game through. you get the most out of the series by playing it this way.
Excellent survival horror; perfect mix of creepy and challenging.

I freaking love the Penumbra series, this game is a brilliant survival horror with an awesome story. Requiem is an odd expansion - no combat, but a good little puzzler.

I'm a huge horror fan but sadly nothing scares me. I've been to some of the best haunted houses in America and I just have fun, but am never actually scared... (perhaps because I know it's all fake-  Silent Hill 2 and 3 were the first games to instill a sense of doom in me. They remain to this day some of my favourite games. I would recommend just getting this one as the first game in the series is boring and the only enemies are dogs and spider -.- and you have a WEAPON to kill them, where in Black Plague you have nothing, ever.  8/10 from me c:

Penumbra Black Plague was as I feel one the best horror games in it's genre, but avoid Requiem at all costs.
Beautiful. This game made me love horror games.

So, there I was thinking myself a pretty hardcore horror-gamer. I played the original, and I must admit it was freaky in the start until one truly masters that pickaxe. So... the sequel comes out and I launch it, preparing to wreck some hell hounds (or whatever the â¥â¥â¥â¥ they are) and step in the footsteps of HP Lovecra...- Eh, the other guy. And then Frictional Games SMACK me in the face with a wet newspaper, point, laugh, and finally lock me in a dark cage in a dark cellar on a dark night... You WILL be sitting on needles, and you WILL be whimpering (if you don't outright shriek like a little girl being surprise-tickled) while forcing yourself to attempt to master the courage of crawling out of the room and towards the next. And if you pretend to be playing this game without shaking, then you are a liar. So what're you waiting for? Get it!

The Penumbra series is an impressive thing to behold. While Frictional Games' follow up title 'Amnesia' managed to improve on this in nearly every way, Penumbra is still a very effective combat-light survival horror game. You might find flaws in the interface, but you'll be sweating too hard most of the time to take much notice.
GREAT GAME!! with scary maps and enimies also puzzels!

Best played alone. In the dark.   The dark atmosphere is a breeding ground for fear, and the interactive environment makes you feel like you're really there (honestly, having to open doors by pushing them open with your mouse might be one of the creepist game mechanics ever). The real trick to making it through is keeping your head: it's hard to solve mind numbing puzzles in a panic, and if there's one thing Penumbra can do, it's put you in a panic.  But don't get me wrong. Running and hiding is usually a very, very good idea.  If you like this, I also recommend Frictional's two other games: Penumbra Overture (the prequel) and Amnesia: The Dark Descent.

A must play for any fan of Survival Horror, a very Lovecraftian story, with chilling gameplay, smart puzzles, and many intense moments. Part 2 is the best, but the whole series is great and I fully reccomend it.

Just like the last game, you explore the environment and solve various puzzles.  This time your enemies are humanoid and you cannot fight leading to stealth being your only strategy throughout the game.  Definitely worth playing.

Very fun game. I suggest buying Overture and this, if you are in the mood for some horror survival. I don't know what else to tell you. It's a horror survival game. We all know how those are already, right? :P There's no defending yourself in this game, but you can in Overture. Of course, your pickaxe in Overture is so weak that I would feel more comfortable saying you're defenseless.
Not too bad. Scary at parts and challenging puzzles

Definitely more scary than Overture as well as the same great story elements Overture had, although I do feel a burning loss from Overture. I felt very immersed in the game. Penumbra Requiem on the other hand I feel isn't the best of the three. It gets rid of some loose ends in the story quite well, but I found the gameplay to be the most boring and perhaps even depressing out of the three games.

Definitely one of the scariest games I've ever played, but that's to be expected from Frictional Games (They made amnesia)  The game plays like an FPS but is filled with adventure elements. The feeling of vulnerability is what causes most of the scares in this game. While a monster slowly creeps around your area, you have to debate fight or flight very carefully due to the lack of any legitimate weapons at your disposal. This is an excellent way to drive the fear of the player to the ceiling. All this is going on while you are figuring out rather complex puzzles and slowly figuring out the mysterious story.  I highly recommend getting the collectors pack for all three Penumbra games and lots of scares!

The puzzles are fun to do, the story is great with the inclusion of Clarence Phillips infected alter ego. The horror was great but not the horror of games like Dead Space or Metro 2033  but the horror of seeing a enemy and thinking if that â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ sees me im â¥â¥â¥â¥ed  but its easy to get away from the enemys in the game i'll give this game a 8/10 If you enjoy stealth games horror games and puzzle games well christmas has come early

Probably the best horror game series ever made... If you are looking for an immersive game, with a good story, nice gameplay and so scary that will make you jump (or scare the living sh*it outta you), I recommend Penumbra.

This is one of the scariest games I've played so far. Doesn't beat Amnesia though. But its very very close. Has a big big dark sense to it and maybe Dark Comedy aswell? At least in my eyes. If you enjoy scary games, this is for you.

Black Plague is a decent horror/puzzle/stealth game. Compared to Penumbra Overture, Overture was better for a few reasons. Some of the scares from Black Plauge were recycled in the sense that how they scared you in the first game was what they also used in this game which lowers the suprise element, at least for me. Black Plauge also brings in a lot of story which is a good thing for a game, but I think they might have overdone it a bit, they tried to do too much at the end. Without spoiling the end, it became very reminiscent of another popular game, story wise. Lastly, the voice in the head was annoying and killed the mood for me.   the good news is as stand alone game not compared to the first, the game is pretty good. It' s hard not to compare to the first game though as the story runs over, and if didn't play the first one, you would be really confused story wise. Anyway, good maps, great atmosphere, freaky creatures, and decent puzzles.  6.5/10
The scariest game I've ever played. The atmosphere is amazing and the story is brilliant.  You have to buy Overture as well because they're really just one game split into two.

Definetly My favorite of the penumbra games, near the ending it gets a bit weird but the rest of it I was on the edge of my chair.

Pros:  - Great atmosphere - Interresting story - Spooky (At times. I would say it's a 2spooky out of a scale of spooky to 5spooky)  Neutral  - The game is very puzzle heavy, and this can either be a turn on or turn off. Read all your notes and use common sense however, and you'll complete most of them without problems (Though some of them are complete bulls**t). - The graphics aren't terrible, but they aren't exactly appealing either. Though 'appealing' was maybe not what they were going for graphically  Cons  - Extremely short, like, 3.5 hours short, and that was with me dicking around, not know what to do for the most part. If you know what you're doing you can complete this in like 1.5-2 hours, honestly. - For a game marketing itself as a horror game, there just isn't much horror here, and what horror is there is kinda sloppily executed. The main monster just looks kinda ridiculous, It's just a white guy with his d*ck attached to his r**tum. Plus, you can take a handful of hits before dying, and the AI is dumb as dogshit. The game is like 65% puzzles/exploration and 35% horror.  Overall: A weak 7/10

a VERY successful horror/suspense puzzle game. I found that the story was entralling (even though I never finished the 1st game: Overture of the series) and the 'enemies' were often not a major part of gameplay, I enjoyed that it was more puzzle based then run/hide/jumpscare like so many recent games (outlast, Alien: Isolation, and even Amnesia) It really beconed back to the 'golden age' of adventure games, with most puzzles making logical sense and playing out in a physics based world (ala portal). Very reminiscent of Sanitarium in that you really got the 'horror' more from ambiance

Old and dated graphics aside, the environment is extremely immersive, very well paced and very worthwhile challenge. Its a true series, each game picks up where the last game ends. We need more games like this.   Simply put, the Penumbra series is awesome. Play all 3 games, you wont be disappointed.

A natural, good progression from Overture in terms of plot (and I really like the way the main menu music has changed to reflect how things have changed).  As in Overture, the writing feels sophisticated and the actual execution of the game feels quite OK most of the time (I am not really a large fan of puzzle games, but it worked for me as it was well-integrated with the progression of the storyline).  Some people apparently don't like the ending. While I am note completely sure whether there are some logical holes in it (there's a lot to consider and remember), it does otherwise actually makes perfect sense when you consider one important and central detail of the larger plot. I quite liked the ending, actually.  If the Penumbra games are on sale, they should definitely be bought - IMO.
Creepier and more intriguing than Overture with a great ending. 3/5 mankinds.

This is definitely the scariest game franchise there is, and this is coming from a guy who has been a fan of horror/scary games for a long time, i have played almost every horror game and franchise there is (Resident Evil, Silent Hill, Clive Barker's, Fatal Frame, Condemned, Siren, Clock Tower, Alone in the Dark. System Shock, The Grudge, Cold Fear, etc...) and no franchise or game comes close to Penumbra, scariest one i have ever played for sure, the only game that could surprass it is Amnesia.  Black Plague is the scariest one  Requiem is the less scary one

I played this game off steam before so don't mind the 30 minute playtime. I invested quite a lot of playing hours into these games and I have never come across another series that did it quite like Penumbra. Satisfying story, excellent visuals, extremely well done suspensful moments coupled with probably the best interaction to the environment I've had ever. You really feel immersed in this world and invested in the task to uncover the story. I love these games.

The Black Plague is a significantly shorter game (no more than five hours, generally) than it's predecessor, Overture.  However, it's brevity is compensated by substantially more story and answers to players' burning questions on what the hell is happening in game.  Penumbra: Black Plague still suffers from a lack of variety in monsters and challenges, though the enemy is far scarier than the models used for Overture. The Penumbra series in general is quite lacking in versatility and diversity of puzzles and challenges, but nevertheless makes for a very interesting adventure.  I would recommend playing the first game to get the full story, but to be completely honest, Overture does not provide much at all to the story of the overall series, and Black Plague could be played alone with the majority of the themativ understanding still intact.  Bottom line: The series in general has a brilliant story, but being an older game, suffers from repetitive puzzles and challenges. Overture lacked these excellent story elements, and Black Plague, while scarier and more immersive, was shorter and yet more repetitive. Together, the experience is fascinating albeit simple.

This game... jesus christ... this game scared the living â¥â¥â¥â¥ out of me. If you like horror games... this is a horror game; its etremelly scary but fun and challenging. I personally love it, but i can not play it at night or with the recommended settings (Headphones, Lights off, Low screen lighting).

The developers cut the disappointing parts of Overture (combat and weak/confusing story) and added an impressive amount of depth and plot on top of the existing foundation.  This game is an exciting narrative with mostly interesting physical puzzles sprinkled throughout. A couple of the puzzles felt tedious to me, particularly towards the end. I didn't find the story to be particularly profound, though.   Even more dissapointingly, I had hoped more than anything that the game would build on the immersive, horrific atmosphere of the first episode, and genuinely creep me out even more, in the same way that SOMA did. I found that the game fell well short of this. Maybe it was Penumbra saturation, but this episode hardly felt like a horror game at all. For 2008 tech, the world and graphics are spectacular and hold up well, but it felt like a video game and not the horrifying universe I wanted to wade into for a few hours.  Fricitional -- as ever -- gets my strongest recommendation for a fun, thoughtful game that emphasizes story, atmosphere, and puzzles above shooting guns for 5 hours.

Black Plague, sequel to Overture, is yet again an astoundingly good game. Several of the wonky game-mechanics of it's predecessor, chiefly unweildy melee combat, have been scrubbed.  The story, progressing ever onward, is well written from beginning to end. For a game like this, with low production values and a small dev. team, to weave such an interesting story is quite the accomplishment. It even has an ending which noticeably stirs the subtle messages earlier in the game.  A genuinely eerie game, though incredibly satisfying to progress in, figure out, and ultimately beat, Black Plague is a great game, through and through, and should definitely be tried out at the very least.  Unless you don't have what it takes? Can you play Penumbra end to end without fiddling with your gamma? Muting your sound? Reading through walk-throughs? I highly suggest avoiding the aforementioned. To do so would be to defeat the purpose of the game, and really take from the enjoyment of it all.

I love the Penumbra series, I think that in terms of 'scare factor', it's one of the best games from the trilogy.   But  In saying this, the game lacks a decent storyline. Although it isn't bad, it isn't nearly as immersive as Penumbra: Overture's storyline and in fact, sometimes Black Plague's storyline can get a bit dull. So why am I recommending this game? Because I still think that despite what I've said, you will still get quite a lot of fun out of this game if you pay attention to the 'finer' details.  If you want to pretend that you're a badass by saying 'this game isn't that scary', trying playing it with the lights out. Livestream it, I'll be sure to watch -_-
like a bag of chips, not lasting for long but good and enjoyable. Larens/10

I've played only a tiny bit of this game at the time of writing but I have never played something so consistently scary...Forget Hiding behind your Assault Rifle and Body Armour, you have no other weapon except your wits to protect you from the darkness...Creeping through Dark, abandonned offices, surrounded by noises...You're alone...Wait! Was that sound in your head? Who's there? Friend or Foe?  This game is truly one of the few games that uses both Sight and Sound to maximum effect...Without any weapons or means of deffending yourself, you must switch off the lights and Hide in the very shadows that hunt you...Only will your ears tell you if it's safe...But then again...In a place where strange noises are in abundance, nothing can be rellied upon. Caution Advised.  Play it in the dark all alone on until dark for a truly scary experience...  One of the greatest games in its genre...Too bad about Clarence...
Super scary, lot's of thinking, some stealth, auto-save and check points everywhere <3. Also smooth, no grpahics or start up problems.

Great if you loved Amnesia:TDD but wanted a more active, involved story and dynamic dialogue and interaction with the environment. Has an in-depth 'checking' mechanic that lets you look at stuff, and dialogue throughout the game with a 'charming' 'companion' that 'helps' you out. Practice your sneaking skills, this is some Metal Gear Solid levels of dodging through corridors, avoiding enemies. Enemies that do NOT disappear after losing track of you. Weird ending, but intriguing and cool nonetheless.  short: Fun, similar to Amnesia (same developers), challenging sneaking portions, actively involved story and dialogue. Screw Requiem, at least it's free.

A surprisingly great game for the price I got it for, which was around 2 dollars on sale. It requires actual thinking and brainpower to get through certain areas of the game which is a trait most modern games lack. I personally think it has aged well and while the graphics wouldn't be considered the best of the best, they hold up well and will by no means affect the quality of gameplay, which is great. Strongly recommend, both as a good deal and as a surprisingly intriguing game in and of itself. You also get two expansions or whatever which I haven't tried yet, which just makes this deal that much better.  Edit: After playing both Black Plague and Overture, I realized Overture is actually the first game in the series so I suggest playing that one first.

Since I'm in a reviewing mood I thought I'd write a review about this game.   Honestly, I really wish there was a 'Meh' button for reviews instead of giving it a Positive or Negative because that's exactly what this game is, however I'm leaning towards Yes so I'll give a positive review.  Penumbra Overture is the first in the series, the game after this is Penumbra : Black Plague and you have an additional game which is Penumbra : Requiem which is just a puzzle-solving one. These games are surrounded in horror, puzzles and story telling.    Length/Replay Value   First thing that pops in to my mind when I'm purchasing a game is the actual length of the game and how much replay value it has. I purchased this game at the end of 2014 and didn't really touch it up until this day where I managed to finish it in pretty much one sitting. This game on average will take around 5-6 hours to complete... yes I said it... 5-6 HOURS! To me, I think that a horror game such as this deserves much more time to it. Is this game one I can go back and play? Not really. Maybe in a few years since I finished Penumbra : Black Plague a few years ago and now I've got the urge to play it again but other then that there isn't really anything to do in the game. No collectibles or anything like that. Just a game which requires you to avoid dogs, solve puzzles and be trapped in some creepy atmospheric mine. The replay value just isn't there.    Graphical   The game was released in 2007 and still looks pretty damn good considering it was released almost TEN years ago! Of course, it won't be as good as modern day games but for it's time I would have said that this game was great and it still is!    Gameplay   The game itself is actually very immersive, the music is creepy which really adds to the scary atmosphere and you are stuck underground in mines/caves with flesh eating dogs after you, massive worms and caves full of spiders, solving puzzles and trying to survive. Sounds cool right? Weeelllll... the game does start off great, the first time you enter the mine and hear the sound of a dog really does shake you up! But as the game progresses you realise that there is a lot of repetition that is used. You see, throughout this game there are sections where the level layout is very identical... similar looking corridors and mines which branch off different ways to different rooms which require you to go to in order to get specific items to progress and using them specific items to open a 'locked door' in one of the corridors. It gets boring after a while and what makes it even more boring is that the monsters that roam the corridors/mines are just dogs. In the caves there are spiders and there is a part with a worm but we're talking corridor/mine sequences... pure dogs. Unlike Black Plague where that had the Tuurngait [ http://penumbra.wikia.com/wiki/Tuurngait_Infected ], this one had dogs that you had to constantly avoid and could easily be avoided by throwing beef jerky around and locking them in cages. The Tuurngait actually carried flashlights in some stages and could see you in the dark, the dogs couldn't do that. I went through the game without getting spotted by a dog once because all I did was wait corners and wait for them to pass. That's another thing that annoyed me, Dogs are supposed to have really good noses and be able to smell stuff better than a human can yet they couldn't smell a sweaty guy trapped in a mine who was sneaking behind them or right around a corner, staring them in the face?    SCARE Factor   Now this is a hard one, I don't know if it's because I'm getting older but games don't seem to scare me as much anymore unless it's a jumpscare but we all know they're no good in a horror game master-piece. Amnesia seemed to get it right. Back on point, this game had no jumpscares but was actually quite creepy when I played it briefly in 2014. If hiding from dogs, running from spiders and worms is your cup of tea then good! The atmosphere was kinda creepy? Personally though, this game didn't really have me scared or on the edge of my seat, If I was to rate it out of 10 on scare factor I would give it a 3.5/10     OVERALL   The game itself is quite an interesting game to sit down and play if you're in to puzzle solving and a slight bit of horror at the same time. It isn't that long and isn't on the edge of your seat scary so if you're someone with a weak heart and who hates scary games then this may be for you! Would I say it's worth it's price? Yeah. However, Black Plague was scarier in my opinion. :)

Penumbra: Overture is the first in a series of horror games released in early 2007. While the developers like to class this as a first person adventure game, I would also say there is quite a lot of elements of survival horror and psychological horror.   The game uses a game engine called Newton Game Dynamics which is known for it's physical and realistic simulations. The adventure portion of the game focused a lot on physics based puzzles as well as a physics based combat system (i'll get more into that later). You can also play a lot of this game as stealthy as possible. The AI in Overture is well coded and respond realistically to noises and light. There are also no guns or fire arms so your combat mechanics are based around manual weapons such as hammers and pick axes.   The combat system is the one aspect that I disliked to begin with; it is very hard to control as you actually have to swipe your mouse in the movement you would like to hit the enemy. It can sometimes get very confusing and you may end up turning your camera 180Â° without wanting to, then getting smacked in the back of the head, which at times can be the difference between life and death. I found I was able to get to grips with the technique eventually, it just took a lot of actual conscious thinking when I needed to use it. It's certainly not a mechanic I would like to see implemented in other games, at least not in this form.   Your main focus when playing is on exploration and classic adventure game object and item interactions. Most of the puzzles require searching for keys or other objects which can be placed in another object, such as batteries or motors. All of the puzzles resolution can all be found in the game; there are no wacky puzzles that are really impossible to work out. Clues can be found in books and letters, which again are found all over the game. The game is split into four chapters, each of these chapters has one 'big' puzzle which may stump you for a while, they normally involve some sort of maneuvering of some kind, for instance my favorite is a steam pump floor and you have to memorize the pattern in which steam is pumped out of the floor, that puzzle alone takes a ton of thinking and memory skills to progress.   Graphically, Overture looks like a 2007 game, this is not a bad thing - it's just very dated. At the time this would of been a very good looking game. There are however fan made texture mods which make the game look amazing, and if you are confident in installing these type of mods, I would highly recommend giving it a try.   As with most horror games, the music and audio plays a massive role in Penumbra. Like I said at the start, this game has a lot of physiological horror elements. At times there isn't actually anything physically to be scared of, however the music tempo changes and suddenly you start hearing thumping sounds, then all of a sudden you are on the edge of your seat wanting to throw your headset on the floor. Penumbra does the audio side of things brilliantly; in fact if you we to play the game without sound on at all, it wouldn't even be remotely scary.   The story mode of Penumbra took me about four hours to complete, which is a solid amount of time for a adventure game like this and I was ultimately happy with the conclusion. Luckily you don't have to pay for each of the games in the series individually, so the price for all three is very well compromised with the length of the game.   I didn't have any technical issues with the game either, the game runs at a silky smooth 60 fps, and can be played at full higher resolutions which is always nice to see from older games.   If you are a fan of the horror and/or the adventure genre of games, you will certainly find alot of enjoyment in Penumbra. This is certainly a series that I am looking forward to playing the next installments of in the future.   If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at  http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/    http://store.steampowered.com/app/22180

Would you like to know what was before Amnesia? If yes, Penumbra is for you as you have a chance to see the first survival horror game of Frictional Games.  Although not as terrifying, Penumbra Overture is still a relatively scary and interesting game where you pick up the story of Philip who has just arrived to Greenland to find his father based on the mysterious letter he'd received from him. To make it even more interesting: Philip had always thought his father had been dead.  The game puts emphasis on physics-based puzzle solving and physics based combat. Combat would be a bit harsh as usually the best thing to do is to run and other than a pickaxe or hammer we will not have any weapons at our disposal. Now, similarly to Amnesia, the protagonist has his own notepad where he writes his thoughts so this is how the story will gradually progress.   While somewhat short, Penumbra showed something new in this genre and those who liked the Amnesia games should definitely give this one a try.

The best horror game I've ever played. Most of these days games rely on jump scares to temporally tug away at the player and is something there for twitch streamers and such. Penumbra will always hold a heart in my place where true horror, scare, and story blend in together.  My father, Howard, abandoned me before I was even born. And here I go following his footsteps, but this time, I won't make the same mistakes. That's all I know...  If you are going to play this game, avoid killing things. It makes things boring, and attacking is entirely removed in its sequels. Focus on avoiding and running away.  I swear, I've never muttered to myself 'I'm so damn lonely' in a game except this one. Its atmosphere is too great. Never seeing a single human being, only hearing someone, and your character's thoughts (which suspciously relate too much with me. maybe it's an edgy thing with me)  You're tucked away at some old abandoned mine with almost no hope to escape and you're not even sure why you're there in the end.
This game is my favourite horror game and I have played alot of horror games. The story is great and don't want to stop playing. If you like Amnesia I think this game is for you.
One of the best games of the genre i have ever played.  Great History and Investigation.  9/10

By removing the Shooter element from the FPS, 'Penumbra' created an eerie FIRST PERSON SURVIVAL PUZZLE genre that surprisingly features some unexpected, nicely paced, action sequences without any direct combat from time to time. You can actually melee some foes or trap them but you'll most likely just sneak past them in the dark (unless you're being swarmed by spiders). The interface is mostly a point and click plus, where not only you get to combine elements to make your way through doors and passageways in endless halls and corridors, you also get to interact with the environment in 3D (with the occasional frustration of not turning a wheel quite right to open a hatch or not thrusting a rock hard enough to break something). It's indie games like this that paved the way for something like 'Alien Isolation' and it's still today one of the coolest games out there with a great storyline and level design. In some ways I prefer this to 'Amnesia', specially because here the dark is your friend and doesn't drive you mad like in the later game (A mechanic that was introduced in order to force you to use lights as if it was food, to recharge your sanity).

'Every time, itâs harder to pull out. Every time, I feel more of myself inside.â    Penumbra: Overture represents the first of three episodes in the Penumbra series. The game offers an immersive horror atmosphere with interesting puzzles and a very strong storyline, which continues straight into the sequel Penumbra: Black Plague.   The only disadvantage of the game is the stiff and sometimes frustrating combat system. Therefore, stealth should be prioritized over combat.    Achievements:    The game has no Steam achievements.

Penumbra: Overture is a first-person survivor horror game with problem solving puzzles implemented in the gameplay which focuses more on survival and eerie atmosphere rather than action and gore. It is also the first episode of the trilogy.  The story centers on Philip, a 30-year old physicist, who gets a strange letter from his supposedly dead father shortly after his mother dies. This gives Philip the inceptive to follow his fatherâs clues, leading him to an abandoned mine in Greenland where he eventually gets trapped in after the mineâs entrance collapses behind him. From then on, Philip ventures through a series of events which turn out creepier with each new discovery he makes. Soon he realises that the mine is not just any ordinary mine. More importantly, it is not actually abandoned. The mine is in fact the habitat of ferocious mutated dogs, ârock wormsâ and spiders. Creepy crawly spiders.  Surprisingly, the game has an intriguing story even if its premise of searching for your lost father as a plot device has been done numerous times before. Perhaps that is due to the fact that the story, or maybe its narrative, is actually pretty well-written. Generally, most of the story is being unravelled as the player discovers more lost documents and journals from various people who worked in the mine but died in the end in various circumstances. This may require quite a bit of reading to understand what and why things are happening that way (although some things are still left unanswered by the end), so it is important not to have a short attention span. Additionally, when a particular survivor by name of âRedâ makes his first appearance, things seem to get even more interesting from a plot stand-point, in a way reminiscent of Andrew Ryanâs debut in Bioshock.  The gameâs mechanics primarily focus on point and clicking with some 'mouse swinging' when solving puzzles and small occasions of combat mixed in. Although some puzzles may require a lot of thinking than others, they are by and large well implemented. Unfortunately, there are times when backtracking is required which may or may not become annoying in time. Furthermore, the game does allow you to hide behind objects and block doors to prevent hostile enemies from seeing or approaching you respectively, thus creating a pretty basic but functional stealth mechanic.  Penumbra: Overture also boasts a great sound design with its spine-chilling ambient music and close attention to details such as foley sounds, as well as having a memorable soundtrack -- the title soundtrack shall always remain a favourite of mine. Sound design is crucial for horror games like Penumbra: Overture, and it is reassuring to see that the developers did a fine job here.  Graphically, while the art direction is commendable, the game did not age too well by todayâs standards. The animations are rough and stiff most of times, particularly for the dogs. But in most parts, the aesthetics do achieve in creating the spooky environment the developers envisioned.  The major downside of the game is its combat mechanic. Just like the way you have to approach the doors, drawers or switches in the game, the combat here requires âswingingâ the mouse which is extremely clunky and requires a lot of practice before getting the grips with it. Sadly, the experience generally ends up being always infuriating for every single hit stupidly missed by your pickaxe (arguable the main combat weapon). This is why any combat should be avoided as much as possible in this game, at all costs. On top of that, there seems to be a lack of variation in enemies too.  Conclusively, Penumbra: Overture is a game which excels in creating an authentic horror experience with genuine eerie atmosphere and plenty of mystique, along with well thought-out puzzles and an unexpected interesting story, only let down by its combat mechanic and roughness from a technical perspective. Being a relatively short game (so long as you do not âwasteâ time standing in one spot due to fear), it has the perfect length and pace. It may not be the most impressive horror game out there on the surface, but it is one which horror enthusiasts must try thanks to its unique approach and emphasis on atmosphere and less on combat which differentiates itself from the masses of generic and/or action-oriented horror games; in addition to paving the way to future superior, if not the best, horror games such as Amnesia: The Dark Descent or even Overture's follow-up episode, Black Plague.
go into a mineshaft and get scared of dogs

The first game by Frictional Games, Penumbra stands as the strong debut of the devs. Although the combat system is clunky, and the mechanics feel a bit unrefined at times, Penumbra is still a great game that contributed to the more polished and sp00ku Amnesia : The Dark Descent. Both Overture and Black Plague are able to hold their own, with plots that are connected, yet both games give off their own distinct feel. If you're late to the party, (like I,) and haven't bought a copy of the Penumbra Trilogy, you're seriously missing out on sp00ku.

So if you're using Steam OS or playing under a different Linux Distribution, I can absolutelly recommend these games.

Really good game, I had a lot of fun but had to stop about 8 hours in because of the spiders. I thought I would be able to handle them and I was very wrong. If you're scared of spiders this is defintely not the game for you, but otherwise I'd definitely recommend it.

Great game from Frictional Games. I played it after Amnesia and really enjoyed the story.  A word of advise, donât rush trough the game. Read every note you found and enjoy the story and atmospher of total despair.

Rating 6.5/10 Overview: First Person Survival Horror  The Good  + Creepy, haunting atmosphere that takes place in a deserted mine shaft  + Sound effects, music   + Story that slowly unravels told through logs/journals   The Average:  Graphically the game doesn't hold up very well. Textures look bland, the environments have a 'copy and paste' feel to them   Some levels are frustrating  Frustrating auto save system that will save just as you are getting attacked forcing you to use earlier saves.    Enemy animations   The Bad :  A lot of puzzles are very unclear in how to solve them    Conclusion  It's obvious this game is showing its age and not just graphically but also in its level and puzzle design. However I still found it decent for a survival horror game and worth checking out at a discounted price. Just be prepared to use a walkthrough to avoid needless frustration.

Penumbra: Overture is a great puzzle/horror game. Made by the masterminds behing both Amnesia games and the upcoming S.O.M.A. This game has amazing sounds and atmosphere, i recomend playing with headphones for the full immersion. While the graphics arent the prettiest (the game is pretty old) it is still much so worth playing, the story is great and the atmosphere is incredible, definite 8/10 for this one!

Penumbra is a enjoyable experience for gamers who like puzzles and exploration. Dark, Dank, Dissused mines with Vicious dogs roaming around. Spiders, slugs and worms... urgh!  It has a great atmosphere about it and areas are small and quick to progress through. Not too much back-tracking.  The Combat isn't great but then it can be avoided with stealth. If you must fight, then use your nogging and find a way to make it easier for you and harder for the enemy. plenty of stuff lying around to make combat quicker and less annoying. The story gets alot more interesting the further in you get, So don't give up! Oh! and play this game with Headphones as it adds to the spookiness.
I used to like dogs.. and horrors.

This game was quite the experience - though I would like to say it was an entirely positive experience, Im not quite sure it falls into that category. I bought Overture as a part of the Penumbra bundle, and have started Black Plague with skepticism. To sum up my experience with Overture, it would have to be, 'annoying.' Though the beginning of the game provided an amount of excitement, it quickly became borderline unbearable to continue due to the ungodly spiders, the redundant puzzles, the giant rock worm debacle and feeble combat/control system. I honestly had the premonition, 'I will never play this game again.' roughly ten minutes before completing the game; which was all that I had left to carry good old Phillip past the garbage incinerator and into the, admittedly much improved, world of roving, naked 'grey' alien mutations of the Shelter. My advice is to find a trustworthy rendition of the storyline of Overture, and then begin playing Black Plague.

A peaceful start, a few puzzles to learn the ropes... The game is set up. Now imagine that lovely background suddenly turns to an oppressing atmosphere, the anxiosity of walking in every corridor, that sensation of being watched or chased, forced to hide, with no clue what's going despite weird stuff happening all around you...  Penumbra isn't cheap scary game made of screamers. It is a true psychological horror puzzle game, just like an interactive Hitchcock movie that would be mixed with science-fiction elements.   Simple yet terrifying !  Probably one of the best horror game available. I totally recommend getting the trilogy!  Overture  is my favourite episode : truly oppressing, a better setting and more clever puzzles.  Black Plague  will lead you deeper into the plot, gathering suspense and revelations.   Requiem  beautifully concludes the game, and puts an end to this psychological horror tale.

Penumbra: Overture is a very fascinating horror adventure game that takes the player to an uninhabited part of Greenland, into an abandoned mining complex, where the player will experience all kinds of spooky occurences and run into whatever creatures dwell inside. I actually really like it how the player is given the chance to fight the dangers, even though being stealthy is the best option to go with. Or rather, it would be if there were no glitches that the player could take advantage of; the games most commonly met creature can easily be slain by jumping on a crate where it cannot reach you, crouching and hitting it whenever it makes a desperate leap attack towards the player, but to no avail. Also the game seems to crash very often. Then again, thats probably just me skipping puzzles by for example climbing to place x instead of knocking the ladder down with something. Well, lucily those are the only grand minuses of the game that I can think of right now and other than those points, I can't help but recommend this classic to horrorlovers. Why? Because the plot is pretty interesting, the puzzles are semi-challenging and there are parts in the game where you need to think and act quickly in order to survive, this game is basically the daddy of Amnesia: the dark descent.
Creepy atmosphere, interesting story. This is one of the best horror games I've played. I say it's better than amnesia: the dark decent which is made by same people.

This was one of the scariest games I've played, next to F.E.A.R. and some others. Here's my short review:  If you love being scared, exploring and solving logical puzzles, then this game is for you. Most of the time, you will be spending your time avoiding monsters unless you have a handy pick-axe with you.  The overall atmosphere is very creepy, especially when those dogs are near. The music intensifies when enemies spot you which gives you a rush of adrenaline.  The physics are also cool; you can pick things up and move them around.  The story just immerses you with all the text you write in your notebook, the short passages during the loading of the next chapter, and the descriptions that you observe when looking at things around you.  Overall, it was atmospheric, and scary. It requires you to use your brain and create objects in order to advance. It also gave me chills continuously. Note: To me, you cannot finish this game in one sitting.  8.5/10
By the creators of Amnesia. Scarier than Scary Godmother: Halloween Spooktacular.

I Dont normally play horror games as I do not get scared by them often. However, Penumbra: Overture is Different. I thought I would pick this up, just to see what it was like (Also it was Â£1.25 in the Steam Sale). I had no Idea what I was getting myself into....  PROS/CONS  +A really Tense atmosphere: The atmosphere in the game is spot on. Instead of constant jumpscares the game shoves you into a dark enviroment that will have you jumping at shadows and curling up into a mewling ball in front of your computer.  +Sound Design: The sound is immersive and chilling and when you do encounter enemies (Spoiler-dogs) The Nerve-shattering growling will put your hair on end.  +Gameplay: You can physically interact with objects and you have to manually open doors by using the mouse button and dragging it around. The puzzles follow the traditional format of itemA+entitiyB=solutionC and will require you to think logically. You have to manage resources (e.g You have a Flashlight that needs two batteries every hour).  +Story: The story is immersive and clever twists and turns will leave you wanting more.  +Graphics: Good for a small indie team.   -Combat: Unfortunately, this game has a rather clunky combat system. You hold down R and Swing in the general direction of the target with a Pickaxe or Hammer equiped. This is rather annoying in dificult situation as you must stand perfectly still facing the target and if the target is a Mobile, Feral dog the you can expect death. Thankfully, combat is usually never the solution to anything.  -Scripted events: The scripted events are annoying as they reqiure you to do certian things in a certian order. For instance, the first spider cave has you crawl through tunnels , blocking off spiders with boulders. You have a limited amount of time to think and what you have to do is unclear without pausing for thought. The worst experience for me was being chased by a Giant Worm through a chemical storage area. You have to close doors with obsucre buttons, bunny hop across a river of Acid, Use the Awful combat system to destroy a fence and finally, knock stupidly placed physics props over to cross yet another Acid River. Engaging style of gameplay that lets you interact with everything in the environment.   Lots of practical thinking and puzzle solving involved as you explore each level collecting useful objects and papers for your notebook that also tell a good story. (you will need a walkthrough for some parts)   Environments are very immersive and inhabited by predators that will have you on the edge of your seat as you consider each step. If you like Amnesia, this is the developer's first game and it lays the foundation for what came later. It shows in a lot of ways, but it is by no means a terrible game.  For starters, this is the only game Frictional Games has made that feature weapons and combat. This is a good thing, as Overture's combat is clunky and broken. Swinging requires you hold left click, pull to the left or right to prepare a swing, and then swing in the opposite direction to hit. The hit detection is very short-range and the swing area is small. However, the most commonly encountered enemies (dogs) are easy to kill as you can use boxes to stand out of reach of their attacks and simply stun-lock them with your weapon until they die.  The atmosphere is creepy, but all of the story is through notes and you never really encounter anybody else. Aside from some rare jump scares, there's nothing terribly scary because the combat AI is so laughably easy to manipulate. There are spiders in this game, which might make you freak out if you have arachnophobia.  Luckily, the game is puzzle-oriented and there are only a handful of areas full of enemies. Most of the puzzles are figuring out a process of doing something such as turning on a generator or determining a four-number door lock by translating it through Morse code. The Morse Code puzzle is probably the most difficult out of the bunch and merely requires a pen and paper (or notepad) to write down possible combinations; all other puzzles involve manipulating objects in your environment and following some written instructions.  The story ends on a cliffhanger in Overture, so it's recommended you ALSO play Black Plague, which plays much more like Amnesia: The Dark Descent and has much better story presentation. Requiem is technically the third game in the series but is only tangentially related to the other two.  So if you're looking for a horror game that involves atmosphere and puzzles rather than focusing on combat like Condemned or Resident Evil, this is a good place to start. It runs on just about anything at a respectable framerate.

Journeying into an abandoned mine in the middle of nowhere as you seek answers for your past. It is abandoned, but not uninhabited.  One of the more frieghtening games released that plays with a lot of your emotions and fears. Penumbra truly feels terrifying when nothing is happening, and you'll have to overcome your fear of the dark.

Definitely worth checking out if you liked Frictional Games other works.

I didn't find this game quite as scary as Amnesia, but it is still a good game. The stealth was not done as well as Amnesia, either. Getting around the dogs was surprisingly a piece of cake, only being caught at least 3 times, but you can just hit them, and run away while they go for help, and you'll be all good. The one thing I really hate is the way you attack, having to hold down the mouse button and then move the mouse around. This makes it difficult to stay aiming in the direction you want. If all you had to do was click to swing your weapon, it would make aiming a lot easier. I died a few times because of this problem. I can only hope that Black Plague doesn't have the same thing.  And I really hated the part with the chemicals. The labeling of each chemical made no sense, there was nothing giving a hint as to which one was which. I though the order they were numbered on the paper was the same order as the letters on the vials. I looked through a couple note regarding explosives and chemicals, but they didn't help at all. I had to look up the combination. I tried to make sense of the labeling of the chemicals, but I just kept seeing people guessing. I still can't find out how it is supposed to make sense, with the numbered order being different than the letter order.  But besides that, I still think the game was cool.

This recommendation applies to both the Overture and Black Plague episodes of Penumbra.  Both remind me a little of the survival-horror System Shock atmosphere, crossed with a classic puzzle-solving adventure game. There are also small homages to Half-Life in the story and gameplay.  If you like spooky atmosphere mixed with a bit of action and puzzle solving, you'll really like the first two Penumbra games.  Avoid Requiem, however. It's little more than a Portal-esque rip-off with some horror tidbits thrown in. The only possible reason to bother with the episode is to see the ending, which ties in to the first two and adds an extra layer to the story. But it's really not worth the price of admission, unless you can pick up Requiem super-cheap.

It is a jump back into time as the game came out in 07, and the method to opening doors is to right click the mouse button while your cursor is over the door and then move your mouse like you were actually opening the door.   The story is interesting and I'm hoping it doesn't build up to a terrible ending. The combat system is weak and repetitive with most enemies I've encountered so far. While not as polished as later Penumbra games and the Amnesia games it is still a extremely terrifying and mystifying game.The story follows Phillip a physics teacher at a British university but like most horror game characters is an idiot who heads to the middle of nowhere in the ice of Greenland looking for his presumed dead father,unprepared so ends up falling down a old hatch into a old abandoned mine/bunker.He continues further inside the mine to a more modern part of the mine ends up contacting a insane trapped miner 'Red'.He slowly finds out what is really happening in the mine.   There is a sort of crude combat system but I think it shows what a normal scared person would do,swinging pickaxes around trying to hit that thing in the dark,the story,music and dull graphics build a horrible atmosphere which is great and you never want to find out what's behind that door.   The Puzzles are interesting,original but sometimes just really annoying.You use any tools you can find from crowbars to boltcutters.   This game is still a great horror game and will run on pretty much anything!

Penumbra: Overture, while originally a mere expansion of a tech demo by Frictional Games, does a decent job of standing as a full-fledged game. While not quite on par with Frictional's later and more famous effort, Amnesia: The Dark Descent, Penumbra fires off a trilogy that's intriguing in its own right, and just as atmospheric.  Starting out in a cabin amidst a frozen waste, you're presented with little motivation beyond trying to uncover the fate of your presumably dead father. After stumbling your way through a howling blizzard, you clamber down a mysterious hatch and find yourself in an extensive cave system and facility that leaves a lot of questions to be answered. It's not long before you realize there may be someone, or something, down there with you that doesn't want you to find those answers.  As Frictional tends to do with their games, the horror in Penumbra: Overture takes the form more of a looming dread than anything particularly scary. Your powerlessness is repeatedly reinforced, as even something as small as one of the wild dogs somehow roaming the underground can end your day. Using your wits, stealth, and remnants left by those inhabiting the caves before your arrival, most of Penumbra relies on solving puzzles to progress. As you get further in, more and more notes and instructions left behind push you even deeper, eventually toward something no one should have known was below.  Visually, Penumbra definitely shows its age, but things look cave-y enough in the caves and lab-y enough in the occasional lab that you get the idea, and you're unlikely to get lost just because of how things look. Interaction with items feels a bit clumsy, as lifting things just makes them hover in front of you, but the ability to throw or use items and giving things weight appropriate to their apparent mass adds to the immersion of the game. Death, when it comes, is often swift and brutal, but the checkpoints are placed as to not make things too much of a hassle to retread. If you can, remember to manually save now and then, just to be safe.  Other than the awkward interactions and a couple of puzzles being a bit difficult to figure out, there's nothing I really found fault in when playing Penumbra: Overture. I highly recommend picking up the follow-ups, Black Plague and Requiem, if you like the first.

Whoa, Frictional certainly like their abrupt endings, don't they? Heh. However, this one at least has a direct sequel which I'm about to launch into, so perhaps there'll be a satisfying finish to this one yet.    Having now played this in the wake of the also brilliant Amnesia, I have to say...not quite sure why this game's 'spiritual successor' got so much of the praise, when it's a virtual remake of this in a more 'medieval' setting? Sure, Amnesia is perhaps ever so slightly more refined, but it wouldn't exist without this blueprint/'test run' coming first. And any game which keeps me in constant suspense with just a handful of feral dogs, some carnivorous fist-sized spiders, and the occasional epic worm is clearly doing SOMETHING right!    In short, if you adored Amnesia you should at least get a kick out of this one, even if you might suffer a slight case of deja vu...and an absolute MUST-HAVE for anyone fascinated with just where the hell The Dark Descent came from. Underrated!!  Verdict: 8.5/10.

In the late 90's I published a Call of Cthulhu RPG scenario on Cthonian that resides near a coal mine somewhere in Eastern Europe, so this game has been pretty much a deja vu for me.   Unfortunately, the game itself does not stand the test of time.  Graphics is crude. Plot is decent, but nothing more. It is full of Lovecraftian cliches. The characters (character) you meet being affected, implausible. The worst part of the game, however, is physics and controls. Interactions with environment tend to be clumsy, using equipment is very unhandy.  How big is the problem? Well, I tend to avoid all creatures not because I was afraid of them (as it should be in horror games), but because I struggle to omit any fight possible. To simply hit an opponent with a pickaxe was a challenge requiring very high skills with mouse and keyboard. At the same time the enemies are plain stupid (attacking until dead in a repetitive manner) and happen to die in weird positions - dogs drop dead 2 ft above ground, or partly in the wall or in the ground. Again, it's a glitch, not a horror element.  All in all, not recommended (says a Lovecraft fan). I had to force myself to finish the game.

Basically this is a game about, you know, dark things in a place, and you do stuff, and I think monsters attack you? The atmosphere in Penumbra: Overture is great. It's dark, creepy, lonely, and cold. The physics engine is okay, with some flaws here and there, but nothing worth seriously complaining about. The moving of objects and melee actions can take getting used to, but once you're comfortable with the physics engine, it works okay, although far from perfectly. The game flows through the story smoothly without any frustration or senseless puzzles/problems to be solved. Everything is logical and upfront, requiring a realistic approach and a reasonable amount of thinking to proceed. The save system is unfriendly. It seems to save your progress when you update your personal notes, or when you interact with a certain object within the game world, which the player has little control over when this occurs. This means that you will often have to do certain portions of the game over and over until you get it right. The voice acting is superb. The accent and tone are outstanding and adds to the storyline greatly. All of the texts you will encounter in the game are well written, interesting, and adds plenty to the plot. The controls can be awkward at times in order to accomplish some actions the game requires. Penumbra: Overture is not a scary horror game. Most of its interesting emotional influences on the player comes from the theme of being almost completely solitary in an unknown place that is far from civilization and darkness. There are some instances in the game that requires the rapid change of items in conjunction to platforming and running, which I had to do many times to get it right. There is also a surprising amount of platforming as a whole for a primarily adventure game. Some parts of Penumbra: Overture are really cool, there is no denying that, but it does have a feel of an unpolished low budget title. With that said, this is probably one of the best adventure games I have ever played. It is logical and tense at all the right moments. I am not entirely sure for how long the main character is inside the mine, but the glow stick lasts for the entire duration of the game. You are not forced nor expected to use the flashlight nor the flares, which have finite longevity. I found melee fighting to be clunky and awkward, but this did not detract from the overall gaming experience. The ending is very creepy and will keep you glued to the plot, even though there is much left without explanations. The only major downside is the game's length. It is somewhat short and leaves you with a feeling of unfinished business with a cliffhanger.  Penumbra: Overture is good.
Sorry not played the game yet, I just wanted to be the 1.000 review! I'll come back and do a proper review once I've played it :)

Just finished it and I gotta say this is one good horror survival game. Though it's now more than 7 years old, it's not bad looking. Not pretty but good. The controls take a little time to get used to but they're not awkward. The atmosphere of the game is just awesome. The music though there's very little of it also helps to create the feeling of tension. The story is mostly told by notes you'll find but it keeps you interested.   The only bad points I could say are some annoying parts where you're chased and need to find your way before getting killed. They can become frustrating......damn spiders! Also sometime the cursor won't appear yet you need to click on an item to do something. It will work if you click but if someone waited for the Icon before clicking they could miss something. These are minor things that should not keep you away from this great experience.  My advice is to save often with the strange artifact (glowing orange lights on it) or you can rely on autosaves. Get the Collectors Pack which has this game, the second part (Black Plague) and it's expansion so when you finish one you can jump straight in the next part. Really worth every penny.

The game fell short at the end (figuratively and litterally; you can beat the game in 8 hours). You won't miss much if you just read a summary of the story on the internet. The game really sets a good scary atmosphere though, but it never gets as scary as I hoped it would be. The dogs and the spiders just â¥â¥â¥â¥ me off more than they scare me, especially when I realised you could kill them. I know black plague has creepy naked dudes so hopefully it will creep me out a little more.
First boss, thecellar door thing you have to smash with a rock, is too hard. Please nerf.
gr8 game maybe even better than the first part, dont buy the third part 'requiem' tho that has nothing to do with the first 2 games and it sux

I really like this game. Meh. Thumbs up, but not that far up. Decent semi tense horror type game from the Amnesia folks. If you've already played Amnesia, you may want to just pass on this. If you're a huge horror game fan it might be worth your while.

After playing a couple of hours I would say this is definitely a good game. It was my first time in a horror/thriller-puzzle based game and though the graphics and physics were sometimes buggy, I had a good fun. Sometimes the story get lost within itself, with a lot of uninteresting long texts and notes but it doesn't really matter afterall; because what matters is the atmosphere the game creates. Better played at night, in a air-conditioned darkened room, in a 32-40'' TV. Manage to buy the 'trilogy'.

This game is great! Make sure to go right up to the dogs and give them hugs, this makes them fight for you against the far more terrifying enemies. I never knew that and it made the game way harder! Good luck!

First off, I do recommend the next episode, and if you are buying that, this episode will likely come in a bundle with that. But regardless I found this episode to be kind of lackluster.  The game controls like a typical first person game, except the bulk of the gameplay is puzzle solving similar to that found in classic point and click adventure games. These puzzles are nothing special but managed not to bore me too much. There is however a fair amount of finding a locked door then finding a key, literal or figurative, in some random place. Fortunately the areas are small enough that they are not usually hard to find.   Where the episode fell flat for me was the supposed horror elements. In between the rooms with all the puzzles in them there are some kind of mutant dogs or wolves roaming the hallways. These to me were not scary and were just kind of annoying. The strategy for getting past them is generally just walking slowly and hiding slightly out of sight when one is in the way until it moves away. There are some other creatures you come across which you have to run away from and these sections are very trial and error. At least one of the creatures would be scary but when you've played the same part repeatedly because of the trial and error nature of the gameplay, it loses any scariness it once had.  There isn't a whole lot to the story. You're trying to enter an underground facility to find out what happened to your father who mysteriously dissappeared. There are various obstacles in your way and some crazy guy talks to you over a radio to guide you along. If you were to start with the second episode, you'd find yourself in the middle of the facility without knowing how you got there but there isn't really that much necessary background information needed to enjoy the second episode.

Visually, this games lacks, but the game is older. The story, music, and atmosphere are pretty good ad the games certainly gives u the creeps. The problem I had was the game doesn't want to load in properly and would make my screen start twitching to the point where it was unplayable. And the save points were horrible. Several times the game would save right in a bad spot where it would load, and u would be dead 5 seconds later.  Maybe an older computer will have more luck, but not recommended by me.

ible, Terrible, Terrible combat controls. âTryingâ (and I put these words in quotations) to swing my hammer to kill the dog, frustrated me to extreme anger. If you could swing the damn hammer and not feel like an epileptic trying to actually land a blow on the enemy, the game's combat would be fine! You have to push down the mouse button and then violently swing your mouse left or right. The direction achieved has to be random because either it does NOTHING or it spins you in a very non-useful direction. Terrible, Terrible, Terrible combat controls.

I played it for about ten minutes, then something spooky happened, I almost wet my pants, turned the game off, and hid under my bed quietly sobbing. I was very surprised on how much scarier the game becomes as you get closer to the end. Very good game, great start to the series, and ultimately one of the best horror games i've played! Although it has taken me a little more than 5hrs to finish this game, it seemed like a very long time. From the moment I clicked 'New Game' I was detached from earthly boundaries. At first I was scared and jumpy, but after a while I thought 'enough', I got up and killed that damned zombie-dog, and it was so satisfying. I strongly recommend this game for anyone in need of some of that horror rush. Remember kids: Badly Administered Dopamine Clouds Frequently Everything.
Penumbra is an amazing psychological thriller title that has a truly enthralling plot, and an interesting control system.

This is the best game of the series for sure. It features a very well developed narrative and constantly kept me wondering what the hell was going to happen next. The horror aspect was spot on and kept me on my toes. This title is well worth your time and money
