Amazing horror game, a masterpiece of the genre. His physics engine and lighting effects are main responsibles for the great immersion and your inability for defend yourself make you feel a despair's sensation through the whole game. 10/10!  Also, I'm too sexy for you to disagree with me.
Wonderful. Not up to par with Amnesia, but a great early effort by Frictional.
just wow. this is something 10/10 i would play anyday and its not an easy game either its quite challenging for someone who has never known about penumbra before. Now onto the next one!

I played Amnesia before Overture, so I was expecting a more flight or die kind of gameplay. It was shocking to me when I discovered I could kill the creatures in the game. I won't say what they are as to not spoil it for anybody. Anyways, right from the get go I was interested to find out where the story was going, more so than I was with Amnesia. Albeit the settings in Amnesia are better, I do find the story better in this, and I like how it is episodic.   I felt the combat to be clunky, but it got the job done. More of a thriller than a horror game. I just finished it, and now I am currently installing Black Plague, I most certainly want to see how this finishes. I won't state 'if you're a fan of...', but check it out if you're wanting a good story in a pretty atmospheric world.
just had to buy it, BEST GAME SERIES EVER!!!

Interesting enough game to keep you hooked. My BIG complaint is the programming of the mellee weapon attack. It IS hideous, really. That...coupled with having to un-equip a mellee weapon before you can interact with objects or function buttons/activations really makes things very awkward. Even though these are 1 handed weapons you still can't press a button, grab a door?? It seems like the game wants you to use environmental mechanics to deal with deadly creatures...but that very odd equip...un-equip combo in the heat of battle gets very annoying & makes things a ton more 'fingers & thumbs' than they need to be.  Base generic enemies too. But, otherwise a goodish time... :-) Only recommended when on sale. I think I paid $2-$3 for all 3 games...so yeah good for that...any more...not sure...

For those of you who have played Amnesia, this is much like it- execpt you can actually fight, albeit with rather ineffective weapons such as a hammer. That's right. Though it isn't the 200 pound battlehammer that one might be expecting. For those of you who haven't, well, it's a horror game. Long story short, it's set in the early 2000s. There's this guy named Phillip, whose father goes missing around the time of his birth and whose mother dies some time after. Phillip grows up and, after 30-ish years, gets a letter from his father, who is supposedly dead. Anyway, he becomes obsessed and tries to find him. His biggest lead is an abandoned mine in Greenland. That's where the game begins. Phillip- the main character- wanders through the cold, desolate and hostile mine, searching for answers. Along the way, you can find letters and things like that explaining the backstory of what's going on.  The game is pretty creepy, although playing it with a walkthrough in an open tab, the lights on and having other people around makes it much less scary than it could be otherwise. I don't think it's as scary as some other games, especially the sequel, Penumbra: the Black Plague, but it certainly is a good game. My only problem is some parts, especially the puzzles, can be a little frustrating at times. It's okay to check a walkthrough for the hardest things, but don't use one as a crutch like I did.

Captures the claustrophobic fear of being trapped and the madness that sets in during a gruesome struggle for survival. Fighting for your life feels clumsy and frantic at the same time: eventually I lost count of the number of zombie dogs I had wildly and desperately stabbed to death with a pickaxe. The sound design complements the atmosphere wonderfully and you will find your heart pounding in time with the ominous music before long.  Puzzles are intelligent and interesting, sometimes requiring you to use your noodle to decipher codes from written clues or learn how to do something from a field manual rather than simply 'use item A on object B'.  A little difficult and confusing at points but definitely worth a playthrough!
A perfect combination of puzzles and scariness, not to mention a gripping storyline. I highly recommend this game to anyone who loves survival-horror games.

This game is amazing, and I would definitely recommend it... However, the game glitched and if I want to complete it, I have to restart about seven check points back! Agh! I can't deal with those spiders again!
Penumbra overtureis a great game although its not really populular compaired to games like amnesia, or outlast.
If you like making deposits in your pants while playing a game in the dark you should buy this. and by deposits i mean â¥â¥â¥â¥.

A creepy and atmospheric horror adventure. The advanced physics engine makes the experience truly immersive. The highs definitely outweigh the lows and this game breathes new life into an old genre. Check it out if you liked Amnesia!
Scary, and extremely fun as well. Definitely recommended.
80 minutes in and i had nearly pooped myself 40 times! this game is great. a nice lovecraftian mystery and horror. oh the horror! the unfathomable HORRORRRRRRR!

Absolutely fabulous horror game with a great Lovecraftian feel! Being made by the same people as the now more widely recognized game, Amnesia, it definitely delivers a equally entertaining gameplay experience.

This was a lot of fun. Penumbra Oveture was a little bit easier than I expected and I seemed to natively understand all the 'puzzles' so it didn't challenge me much. I also seemed to go to the right place every time so I always had the appropriate items. Very atmospheric and plenty of frights. I was a little disappointed at the lack of variety with regards to the enemies especially when I realized how powerful the pickaxe was. Definitely worth your dosh.

The spiritual precursor to Amnesia, and far better imo. The puzzles in this game actually feel like puzzles and not 'THROW â¥â¥â¥â¥ AT MACHINES UNTIL SOMETHING HAPPENS' which was prevalent in Amnesia.  This is the first game. Next, play Black Plague. Reqium is a bunch of random puzzles that have no connection to the over-arching story, you can skip it if you'd like.

probably ranked in my top 10 favourite games i've ever played. even with mediocore graphics this game will scare the living daylights out of you! there's been more than one time when i've had to say 'NOPE', hit pause/rage quit and take a little/big break before trying to attempt playing again. 20/10

About 30 minutes into the playthrough, I was being terrorized by a dog with glowing eyes that really thought I was made of bacon. I finally got to a door, and closed it behind me, thinking that the dog couldn't get through. I was wrong. The dog broke down the door and I nearly â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ myself. In my panic, I picked up a rock and threw it at the dog; it fell down, got back up, and then wimpered away. 'huh,' I thought, 'I guess that was all I had to do?' the answer was no. The dog quickly changed its mind and came running towards me. I panicked and hit the dog once more with the rock. It just did the same thing again, and I was getting desperate. I hit it once more, and when it was down, began bashing it in the head over and over again with the rock (doing this by moving my mouse up and down quickly) and then... the dog died. I really did not expect that. 10/10 game lets me kill the scary bad guy with a rock.

Awesome game. Loved to finally get to play this... since I have played Amnesia:TDD first. The same type of atmosphere, story and draw as in Amnesia. Puzzles seemed too easy at times, but good enough to make you read through everything and find everything you can to get through the game. This type of game atmosphere for a horror is very rarely matched in my opinion.  Only major difference(possibly con) is the ability to attack the dogs. It made them less of an issue unless you missed if you were throwing an item at them. I just chased them down and hit them with barrels or propane tanks. That sort of ruins that horror experience, though making it more realistic since a normal person could attack with anything around them.
No jumpscares, creepy atmosphere, good music. Really nice game (but short)

Let's get one thing out of the way first: I'd reccomended this game based solely on the experince and story alone and the cheap price ($10 for the bundle with it as well as it's sequels) only sweetens the deal. The graphics, atmosphere, sound design, and story are all top notch. This is also pretty much the game that started the exploration heavy and combat-light based gameplay-style for indie-horror that Amnesia later codified.   I DO have some complaints about the gameplay machanics that anyone thinking of buying this should now about, though:  *The combat is clunky and barely responsive. I can see that were going for for a immerisve and substansal feeling system with interaction beyond clicking a button to swing, but it was implemented horribly. It consists of holding the action button to ready yourself, and using the mouse to swing but it takes such broad movements that it's hard to hit anything and good luck lining up enemies when they can simply step out of your hitzone because you obiously can't move the camera while holding the action button.  *I won't post spoilers here, but some of the puzzles violate common sense or rely to much on really diffcult trial and error along with memorization. Some also do downright underhanded things like requiring you know morse-code with nothing but a code-sheet and no indication how to tell dashes from dots.  Normally I'd trash this game, but the story and art design made up for the short-comings in the gameplay and made worth powering through to the end.

Nice game. Not exactly the scariest horror game I've played, but there is this weird lovecraftian feeling when you don't know what's happening around you. The enemies are you joke, you can just run past them and enter the next door. However, the overall atmosphere is really nice and the puzzles are really innovative. The game even becomes emotional and if you like it, you'll probably want to install Black Plague right after finishing Overture.

Postal 2 is an amazing game! It has a hilarious story line, a vast array of weapons, and a lot of gameplay. In my opinion, Running With Scissors did an amazing job at this game. I recommend it to everyone about 15 or older due to a lot of innapropriate content. I rate this game 10/10.
I played this game through in one day.  Buy It!
Very good mood and atmosphere.  Controls are a bit clunky at times, but overall a good game with an intriguing story and OK puzzles.
If you liked Amnesia: The Dark Decent. you will love this. not only is this game scary its sequel Black Plaque is even more scary than Amnesia. A must buy for Horror Fans.

The design flaws in Penumbra Overture may be off-putting at first, but they will serve to heighten your terror and helplessness. Desperately digging my way out of tunnels while unseen horrors assail my back elicits a familiar response of nightmares where one is unable to move fast enough to get away from what is chasing you. And then you die.

Overture is a puzzle game that for some stupid reason thought that fighting mechanics are a good idea and so they made a bunch of stupidly long puzzles where you get chased while trying to brake a wooden barricade and failing because for some reason the main character decided it's a good idea to shank the wood with a pick.Would not recommend if you hate getting killed by dogs,buy Black Plague instead.

It's clear this game had an assortment of great modern features that were somewhat under-developed at the time of Overture's release, but would eventually - with experience and focus - be appeciated for their innovation when the second game in the series, Black Plague, was released.  I'm not massively into horror games - I lack the nerves of steel required to fully absorb them, but I do love exploring locations rich in atmosphere, with fresh storytelling and immersive sound design bolted on top. Combat aside, I enjoyed my time with this game. I was always interested in how the story would progress (the character of Red was great to listen to and very reminiscient of BioShock's Sander Cohen), and I think the environments, though sometimes lacking creativity, were enjoyable enough to move around in.  The combat however is clearly the biggest issue, which basically amounts to a Benny Hill-style run around a cramped location with you occasionally stopping to turn and smack a crazed zombie dog snapping at your heels in the face with the world's smallest hammer. Thankfully, Frictional Games chose to remove self-defense entirely from the sequel, Black Plague, so you just have to grit your teeth and take solace in the fact the next game will be a much less clunky experience. The story and exploration's still great though, it's definitely worth playing if you enjoyed Frictional's other games.

Before Frictional Games hit the horror genre bullâs-eye with Amnesia, there was the Penumbra trilogy. While lacking the overall polish and well thought out-ness that Amnesia clearly possesses, Penumbra: Overture still delivers when it comes to creeps, tension, and story.
Easy puzzles but good story and atmosphere.
Dogs will never be the same again...
Scariest series i have ever played! Better than Amnesia...

Penumbra describes itself as a 'first person survival horror game'. Actually, Penumbra was the game that defined this genre.  There is no gore - the game completely relies on its incredible eerie, dark atmosphere instead of on blood and guts.  The puzzles are challenging, but not too hard for casual adventure players.  Nice graphics, incredible, dark, sounds and music.

The Penumbra Collectors Pack is only $10, and it contains some of the best survival horror games ever made. It is practically a steal. If you are remotely intrested in survival horror games, you HAVE to buy it. Especially when its on sale. Great plot, characters, gameplay, and atmosphere all combine to make one of my favorite game series of all time.  Keep in mind, they are indie games from 2007 - 8, so they can be a bit clunky. It doesn't impact the experience much, though.
The best game from this epic trilogy, in my opinion. Lots of scary moments, The game keeps you intense and tense, besides not having huge battles. Great game!
6/10  Pros: +Original +Clever +Fun  Cons: -Main enemy are dogs, which I dont find scary  Overall: Pretty good game.
Receommended for anyone! Decently scary but combat system was kind of awkward. Great story and excellent introduction to the Penumbra/Amnesia/Soma set.

Giving this game a thumbs up because the interactive physics engine is spectacular and the first hour of gameplay feels fresh and great. The puzzles are fun to get through because you can pick stuff up and toss things around. It makes the Source engine feel primitive. The sound is also done well-- dissonant soundscapes that make your skin crawl just a little bit. And these shining points are why Penumbra Overture gets a solid 'MEH' instead of a dissentful 'GARBAGE'; read on.  After the first hour or so, the game gets quite mundane. The game begins in the typical 'abandoned mine' game trope, which is one of the worst settings there is, on par with 'the water level that's mostly swimming'. Nobody likes abandoned mine levels, we all just begrudgingly power through them hoping to get to the next area. Unfortunately there is no next area-- the whole game is in this mine. As a result the level design feels uninspired and boring.. because it is. And the one lake area that adds some dynamic to the world is a total non-sequitor.  As is standard for horror, combat is terrible. We are encouraged to sneak around enemies, which does have novelty for the first hour of gameplay. After that, it's just Outlast before there was Outlast.. I grappled with the poor fighting system until I found a reliable way to exploit it and kill the dogs (almost) every time. Running from enemies doesn't increase tension. It never increases tension. It only breaks momentum. The corridors are too long to backtrack through if one has to stop and wait out the dogs, so the dogs need to be taken out back and axed. Crouch down and time your hitstuns.  The spiders are poorly implemented. They can't be killed in any practical sense, and they can outrun you. It's a matter of trial and error, death and respawn, until you've brute-forced the maze to the point of memorizing the right path. There was an instance where I got check-pointed with spiders right on my tail, thus making the current objective impossible to complete. Player death was unavoidable because I hadn't previously been moving along fast enough for a sufficient head start. I had to reload an older save and use hindsight to briskly run through and make all of the correct turns.  Similarly, boss battles are all one-shot kills and require fast environment interactions to get past. Once again, they're impossible to beat the first go-around. But after enough trial and error you learn where to go and what to press. It takes all the tension out of the prospect of death. Good game design involves giving the player the opportunity to analyze and deconstruct the situation in the middle of the action, but Penumbra punishes the player for slowing to look around despite it being necessary to advance.  My guess is that this game was playtested only by the creators, and knowing the lay of each path, were able to breeze through with little difficulty. Uninitiated players, despite Penumbra Overture being a relatively easy game, will inevitably die at certain points in their playthrough, making death expected, accepted, and anticlimactic.  Nevertheless, I still recommend buying the Penumbra Collectors Pack this Winter Sale because it comes out to only 83 cents for each game. Although most of my review was negative, it's fortunate that the majority of the game is puzzle solving with that neat physics engine. This game is worth the 83 cents, and it was fun to see where Frictional came from before I play Amnesia for the first time.

Sure I've only played an hour of this game, but I've already learned everything there is to know about it. It's lame! Your character doesn't have enough motivation for me to actually care about him. Plus his voice sounds really weird, so yeah. The creatures are just kind of there. I mean, a dog? Did they market this game to a community of mailmen? But seriously it's actually pretty alright.

Fantastic horror game with a mysterious story and very intense environment. Good puzzles, making it more rewarding our way into the game and the unveiling of the story. Downside is the combat system, which is mediocre at best.
If you like Amnesia, you'll probably like this. Good horror game.
It's kinda like if Heavy Rain and Amnesia had a baby but that baby was trying to find his way out of an abandoned underground mining complex in Greenland
The mouse is really buggy in the Mac client and renders the game unplayable. :(

Penumbra is a horror game that resides in a special place in the genre of horror games, as it not only tries to scare you but rather makes you horribly miserable and lonely the more you progress. The atmosphere is really well done and while playing I felt more and more isolated, the deeper I went into the mine. If you pay attention to the details and let yourself into the mood, this game will reward you by kicking you in the balls and laughing at you while you whimper on the ground.   So much for the mood part.  The puzzle mechanics are a bit rough and unpolished, which is excusable as this is (one of?) the first games of this studio and you see quite some elements that are later refined in titles like Amnesia.  The combat system (which they thankfully removed in the second part) is pretty wonky and needs a lot of getting used to, the best option is to hide.  If you can forgive the mediocre mechanics and really need to feel down, this is the title for you.

This is the first and, I'd say, best game in the Penumbra trilogy. It is appropriately mysterious, atmospheric and kept me interested till the very end. My only gripe with it is that the challenge of the enemies does not scale well with the experience of the player, so by the end of the game they are not scary at all, more of a nuisance if anything.

I can't say Overture is the best game in the entire series. but it might be worth playing after you've completed all the other Penumbra games.  Tbh, the first time I played Overture I got a little bored. Well, more like frustrated. It was an entirely different style of gameplay than I was used to. I loved the atmosphere but couldn't get into the puzzles because they required me to THINK. It made me realize how differen this type of thinking was versus waht I was used to in most other games.  Rather than give up on the entire seires, I went ahead and started the sequel, Black Plague, instead. That one got me hooked. Then I realized the Necrologue mod was available, so I downloaded and played that, followed by Twilight of the Archaic.   Those three I found a lot more compelling than Overture. But it still deserves a thumbs up for being the first in a unique series of games.
Best dog killing simulator out there.

games like amnesia/soma give me a heart attack figured i'd try what they made before personally found it scarier can kill enemies but too afraid to do it 10/10 would reccomend if you wanna get spooped into a coma

Absolutely phenominal game.  I think an in depth review would take away from the experience of your first playthrough, as half of the fun is in not knowing what's coming.  A masterclass in the horror genre.
This game is seriously awesome. Its very good at creating a tense atmosphere and can even make you jump without using cheap jumpscares. Definitely buy this if its on sale.

Penumbra: Overture can be considered as an Adventure game until one point. And that point is the spider tunnel. Okay, at least for me that is the scariest part of the game (except the worm thing). But the main reason why it's not scary until that point is that you can fight back. You can fight with spiders too, but man they are hard to hit. That's when the game becomes 1000 times scarier. I still love the game since it has a great atmosphere and it's my favorite Penumbra game!

Great atmosphere, some good puzzles, fairly interesting story, and no cheap jumpscares that I can recall. My only complaint is the lack of variety in the enemies, but it hardly distracts from the overall feel of the game.
2spooky4me   I can hardly play it for more than a few minutes without feeling like I am going to have a stroke from pure stress.

I absolutly love the Penumbra series, and this one is where it all began. I will miss Penumbra dearly. If anyone from Fristional Games sees this i hope you are going to spread the news that im sure many many people would want... to make one more Penumbra. Again thank you for making a brilliant game way before Amnesia.
Awesome game! but you need some balls to play it!

This was the first game that introduced me to the works of the great small company named Frictional Games. And as it often happens with 'first's - it's the most impressive horror game for me. When I play it now - I have a huge feeling of nostalgia.  The plot is great. Mystery of the father's letter, the idea of a small man trapped inside an unknown bunker in the middle of nowhere, the enormous size of that underground construction... this is all very intriguing! In this game a lot of experiences were concentrated together. At first, it was like reading a very interesting fantastic book. At second, it was very immersive experience of being trapped in this bunker where the only way out is to go deeper into the unknown. At third it was innovative system of the interaction with ingame objects, where your mouse (and so your hand) becomes your virtual hand. Forth - it was a real true horror game, where scary things are made not of sudden flashes or jump-out monsters, but horror of the atmosphere, vulnerability and loneliness. Fifth - a lot of physical objects that you need to interact with, made the game even more immersive, because you see less scripting and more like simulation of virtual world. There was also a great musical theme in menu that touched me when I first launched the game.  As a verdict I can say that this game is at the top of experience of all games I played. If I hadn't play this game I'd missed a lot in my life. Usually a lot of games for me is just a waste of time, and I wouldn't regret if I had never played them, but definitely not this one.

I went into this game not expecting too much considering the pirice and my experience with similar games... Doing so probably made it all that much better. The puzzle aspects of the game were decent but it was definently rich in story. Make sure to follow the directions in the start of the game.
One of the best horror game

Penumbra Overture, which starts the Penumbra series, offers player some horrifying atmosphere and chilling moments. Works well with headphones in a dark room. Try to make it through without weapons. Good luck.
Very excellent game. well done. great storyline. and outstanding graphics!
Although this game may be a bit dated it's still definitely worth playing through. Created by the same developer as Amensia: The dark Descent.

This game is great, as long as you know what you're getting into. If you're looking for a plethora of things to kill and ways to kill them, this is not the game for you. The few 'weapons' you encounter are tools that are used more for their intended purposes than they are for slaughter. Most of the time you're better off just running away from combat, as the tools don't do much damage anyway.  The atmosphere and the creativity of this game make it an experience that differs from the norm, and this is the real reason to play it. The setting is very eerie and a nod to old survival horror games, placing more emphasis on survival than conflict. The sound effects can be very unsettling, and the ever-present snarls of the wild dogs send a chill up your spine. While not 'scary' in the traditional sense, there are moments where the game will leave you with a distinct feeling of unease.   The puzzles can be somewhat difficult at times, but you can't help but admire their creativity and thought-provoking nature. Notes and letters are more than just collectibles here. Many of them are vital to puzzle-solving and advancement, so make sure you read everything you encounter and pay close attention to clues.  Considering you get both games in a $10.00 package, it's definitely a great value. Though if you don't mind waiting, I picked mine up during a sale for 50% less, which made it even more worthwhile.  Admittedly, I have yet to finish the game. But I'm several hours in and I would already recommend it to those who enjoy a straight-up adventure game as opposed to the ever popular shoot-em-up. Looking forward to finishing this up and moving on to the follow-up, 'Black Plague', which I'm told is even better.

The Penumbra series was Frictional Games first series. Overture is the first game in the penumbra series, it features Phillip who is investigating a letter written from his dead father and ends up trapped in an abandoned mine. The game revolves around surviving and hiding, there are no real fighting mechanisms in the game. You can throw rocks or objects to knock out enemies (Dogs, Spiders, Infected) but after a while they will get back up again and attack you. This is a very puzzle heavy survival game, reading and taking notes are important but also some sounds can lead to become very important clues for some places. If you enjoyed Penumbra and haven't checked out Frictional games second series Amnesia, I would highly recommend it.

Penumbra is Amnesia's long lost brother that very few people know about and is by far the hardest game from frictional games. The atmostsphere is unsetteling and very creepy which is what is expected from frictional. Two thumbs way up 4 this game.
Play this game on bathsalts for added fun!

The greatest surivival/adventure game. Every game you do the same thing, fight many waves of enemies and level up, or just shoot as many enemies as possible, clear out the wave move on to the next area. Not since zelda or shenmue has there been an adventure game like this. Very addicting game, cool story.

Penumbra is absolutely astounding. Being the predecessor of Amnesia it beats the living CRAP out of it in all ways; atmosphere (seriously, crawling on your hands and knees with no weapons, dogs howling around you while you're losing your sanity is intense), music (there is none, which I love, it brings a whole new level to insufferable solitary) and the plot. The monsters in the game aren't the typical 'le slender face' either, just dogs, spiders and demons, the simplicity makes it even more terrifying and certainly plays on your fear of the unknown.

Forget what all the people who don't recommend it say about horror factor in this game, this game is actually not meant to be as horror filled as Amnesia was, where-as this game was meant to play on emotion, as well as the other title, Black Plague does as well. Penumbra Overture, while people may be saying 'Has nothing to do with the main character, just this 'Red' fellow.' it's untrue. Philip has a purpose to coming here in this frozen wasteland and pushing on, and the atmosphere is great if you have an open mind, it's dark, it's lonely, it's scary in the sense that you're trapped with nobody to help you, surrounded by death at every corner.  For emotions on the other hand, there are so many things in this series that play with your emotions, they get you to love characters, only to do something to twist around your thoughts and emotions. I felt so guilty playing both in the series with how strongly I got to know and like all these characters in the games. I'll leave it at that. Want to know what was so tear-jerking? Play the game. That's all I can tell you. While the only complaint I may have for this game is being able to fight the monsters, I love the puzzles, (And I'll admit, I actually do love fighting the dogs.), I just overall love this game so much. Again. Just play this game. It's amazing. (Play Black Plague too!)

I think it's better to get straight to Black Plague. Because you can slay monsters in this game, much of the horror gets lost. There have been still quite a lot of scary scenes, but well. It's just a prologue to Black Plague. I liked it though. The graphics are a bit dated today.

The tenth time you've done so after dying each time is just frustrating :o/   The 'no looking at the monsters whilst hiding lest you panic' mechanic is very good but spoiled by the fact that it's not too hard to kill the monsters once you get the hand of using the pickaxe (a mechanic that's initially somewhat frustrating)  Overall, play Amnesia first. The first of the Penumbra series and developer Fritcional Games' first commercial foray into their unique brand of horror, Overture gets the mood and sense of isolation right from the start. Your quest to discover the fate of your father in a secret base under the Greenland wastes becomes a struggle to survive a living nightmare, and if this kind of horror is for you, you'll absolutely love it.  By far and away the biggest problem is the ease with which you can bludgeon most monsters to death, immediately rendering them unthreatening. Luckily, it's entirely possible (though much harder) to play the entire game without killing anything, and this need to remain hidden or face certain death infinitely ups the fear factor. The sequel, Black Plague, fixes this problem without needing to play in a particular way, but Overture can be just as terrifying with only a bit of conscious effort.  Highly recommended and the game that got me into horror.  From the developer of Amnesia!

It's the year 2000. Going against the wishes of a letter appearing to have been written posthumously by the father you never knew, you venture to the far-off, icy reaches of Greenland to discover a terrible secret. In perfect isolation, you have no one but yourself and your own wits to rely on as you creep through the mazelike underground tunnels of a forgotten outpost, abandoned 30 years before... and as you bypass obstructions and make your way deeper and deeper into the dangerous warren, you discover that you may not be alone, and that there's no turning back.

Very good horror adventure game, predecessor to their newest title Amnesia. I finished all 3 games in Penumbra series, and they are really thrilling and compelling. Best played at night in the dark, quite room!

Penumbra: Overture is a wonderfully dark adventure game based under the frozen tundra of Greenland. If trekking through the deep, dank, and dreary unknown to find your supposedly long dead father and uncover what secrets he asked you burn all evidence of speaks to your inner adventurer, then you'll love this atmospheric adventure thriller from Frictional Games. Penumbra: Overture scares up a 3.9 out of 5.

Frictional Games' first outing. A classic in my opinion and it made Frictional a dev I'll buy games from on release day(or earlier) and have no problem paying full price.  It's not your traditional FPS. There is some shooting but the idea is to keep confrontation to a minimum and just run the hell away from everything because it's so freaking scary that simply staring at the monsters for too long will drive you insane. There are some pretty unique action controls that you probably haven't seen in an FPS before. Some of it is awkward to get the hang of but it all ends up making sense just as SOMETHING IS BEHIND YOU FFS RUUUUUUN!  <3 Frictional Games.

The Penumbra series is one of the only horror series left in modern gaming - story driven, challenging, dark, and believe it or not, scary. People call Doom, F.E.A.R., Dead Space, and Resident Evil 4-5 horror games even though they're no more than just shooters. If you're looking for something more authentic and deep, then give Penumbra a try. Remember to play them at night.

To start: I used to add a longer header describing my reviewing ethos, but it made some reviews too long to submit, so I've left it on my Backloggery page.  Gameplay: Odds are that if you're looking at this game, you've played the Amnesia games. They're pretty much one and the same, these series. In fact, there's such a high probability that you've played Amesia or at least seen Amnesia that I'm not going to bother going into too much depth as far as the gameplay goes. Instead, I'll just keep things shorter and compare and contrast the two. For starters, both games have an emphasis on hiding from enemies, since combat is kinda spotty at best. However, that's by design, so there's not much point whinging about that. Unlike Amnesia, you don't have to worry about sanity. The screen just goes all wibbly whenever you look at the enemy. All in all, there's three things you've gotta worry about: puppies, carnivorous spiders, and the worm. The puppies will patrol the area, but you can distract them with bits of beef jerky... sometimes. It doesn't work all the time, though; even if you've got a whole pile of jerky in front of the dog. The other two you just run away from.  Puzzles are, again, very akin to Amnesia. There were a few puzzles that were kinda annoying or suffered from 90's Adventure Syndrome, but they're generally pretty alright. You can brute force a few puzzles; a favorite solution to one where you have to knock down a ladder is to build a tower of barrels. Yes, that works. I'm still surprised that it works. There wasn't really anything that blew me away as far as clever puzzle design, though. It's just pretty run of the mill puzzle design.  As far as the atmosphere goes, Amesia wins by a LONG shot. There really weren't any gripping moments for me in this game. It's not bad, and to someone who's more susceptible to horror than I am, it might be quite a thrill. However, the game didn't grab me in the same way that Amnesia did. Then again, this is the first episode of the Penumbra series; maybe Black Plague can step it up a few notches. 6/10.  Story: It's a pretty typical supernatural-based story. I can tell a lot of the questions the game brought up (that I didn't find myself asking, actually; the game kinda shoved the questions down my throat) are gonna be answered in later installments, but for just the first game, I didn't find myself really caring all that much. Red should have been a lot creepier of a character, but he was more of an annoyance than anything else. At the end, I didn't feel pity; I just felt relief that I wouldn't have to hear his stereotypical rambling. Also, just because your game is episodic, that doesn't mean that you've gotta have a cliffhanger. It only works if you're really invested in the series. Otherwise, it just seems silly. Oh well; at least they got better at writing by Amnesia. 5/10.  Graphics: I'm quite impressed that they were able to do this much in only a ~300MB download. All of the textures look pretty good, the worlds are pretty well made, and everything just looks pretty good. Too bad that the mine environment didn't allow for much on the art style front. Enemies aren't really too interesting art design-wise, either. Certainly nothing as discomforting as Mr. No-Jaw-McGee. It does get kinda boring looking at mine section after mine section after mine section, but I guess that couldn't be helped. The game will run at 1080p easily, and I'd imagine that if you have any graphics card whatsoever, you should be able to run this game without any problems. For a fair bit of technical finesse from an indie team with an unfortunately lacking art direction, I'll give it a 3/5.  Sound: Frictional has always been pretty good at sound design. While this isn't their best example of sound design capabilities, it is still a good show. It does get a bit silly and overdone at times, but for the most part, it does a pretty good job at setting the atmosphere. As far as the voice actor (singular; Red is pretty much the only one), it wasn't bad. It's only bad that his dialogue made me get rather tired of him fast. As far as the music, there really isn't much. It does set the mood, though, so I guess there's that. 4/5.  Overall scores are: 6/5/3/4; cumulative score of 5.7/10. Overall a pretty middling surivival horror game. Hopefully Black Plague picks up the pace.

I'm gonna be honest here. This was one of the first games I ever bought on Steam back in 2011. Being an idiot, I never really got past it. Well, I decided to sit down this weekend and try and actually finish it. Wasn't hard. I did it.   Penumbra: Overture is a good game. As a horror game, eh...  For someone who hasn't really played horror games all that much, this was a pretty ok start.   Penumbra follows the adventures of a young man as he travels to Greenland upon his dead father's request. When he gets there, a storm hits and he is forced to take shelter in an old mine. Bad idea, as the mine has it's own little messed up histrory.   Pros: -Interesting story -Decent graphics -Very atmospheric -Pretty ok puzzles (especially for people not good at them)  Cons: -Not very scary when you can just kill the enemies...  Really thats it. The enemies can be killed pretty easily and early on. It really kills the mood and prevents it from being a great horror game  Rating: 8/10

The idea of sets of corridors connecting different places is interesting when it comes to live but unless you want to keep dogs alive it becomes quite boring and may discourage players. Then comes the end which I was really impressed with. Parts where it's needed to think quickly make the game even more awesome, really. I highly recommend this game. It's the forerunner to Amnesia, and I think the more interesting game. I like the plot better, the location is also more interesting. Make sure you get all three acts, because it's not until the end that the developers really figure out how to do everything right, and it's fun to see their progression as you get more and more terrified. Great plot, horrifying gameplay, nice puzzles.

A predecessor to the (in)famous Amnesia, Penumbra is a diamond in the rough that incites fear through storytelling and some fine voice acting rather than the overuse of jump-scares and B-movie cliches. What results from this great narrative is a short but truly discomorting game where the fear comes from the pervading sense of dread as you delve deeper venture the mine and uncover more of its backstory.   Though this game is dated in appearance, anyone who found Amnesia to be entertaining will likely feel at home with this game, with the physics based puzzles and Frictional's unique take on horror first established here. After nearly 8 years it still stands strong.

'The Penumbra Series' was created by Frictional Games. As many know, they are the creaters of the none-stop famous 'Amnesia Series'. I first started off with 'Amnesia The Dark Decent', then 'Amnesia A Machine For Pigs'before ever playing Penumbra. I haven't seen any play throughs on Penumbra (nore Amnesia at the time) because I love to be suprised, and love to figure things out myself. With Penumbra, it take almost if not EXACTLY the same game mechanics as Amnesia! Just slightly different in very VERY small ways. And with that being said, that's not a bad thing! I know I may be a tad bit late to review this game since it's been out for quite sometime. I haven't even beaten the game just yet, but I am pretty far, and already I love it! I am thankful that Frictional games takes a good notice at their Mac users (cause i'm a Mac user) and gaming on my Macbook Pro isn't that bad at all. The game runs fairly smooth, and doesn't lag at all. I am impressed with the Story Line as well (which I think most people don't care about in these Phsychological Horror Games.) The story is one thing that makes these games what they are! Very mystical, quite a few jump scares here and there, and it's even better when all lights are off. I have yet to play the other ones (which I did purchase) and am so anxious! I would recomend this game to any Horror Game fan, or someone who just flat out wants a good scare here and there, with a few mid to hard puzzles to solve. I would give this game a 10/10.
A little clunky and tedious at times but captures the madness expertly.
A indie horror game by the creators of Amnesia. I suggest this to anyone who likes Amnesia

This was a great experience.. there were a couple of spots that made me want to hit my head against the wall, but they were well worth putting up with (and probably only added to the experience even more so, in the long-run.)
Be sure to download 'Necrologue' (amnesia mod) if you like this, it is a new episode of Penumbra.

Aside from some bugs this and the following conclusive chapter Black Plague are solid games, sure they might feel a bit low budget but there aren't many games that can quite match this game in creating an suspenseful atmoshphere, and making you want to progress deeper so you can see what the game has in store for you next.

Maybe it's because I've been so spoiled playing Amnesia Dark Descent and Outlast... but this game only spooked me a little bit. The puzzles and figuring out things was fun... but the creatures among the puzzles were just annoying after a while. A couple things did take me by surprise, but over all... I was kind of disappointed.  Story line? 'oh where is everyone? oh what happened to my dad? oh what are these weird lanterns? oh how do i get out'  I finished this game in under 6 hours.  Bug report: early on in the game I had my grab/interact mouse disappear on me. Had to restart.  Controlling was very easy for the most part. Keyboard and mouse. The ONE thing that bothered me the most was having to shake my mouse like an idiot just to swing a hammer or a pick-axe. -.-  Motionsickness? Yes, unfortunately. I think the repetative tight corridors and looking around for clues is what did me in.  Would I recommend this? Well... maybe. I don't know. Personally, if you want a game not as scary as Amnesia DD, then sure... but if you are really looking for loads of OH GOD MY HEART! then... I'd actually say skip it. o_o  Don't get me wrong, it wasn't bad. it just wasn't great.  I think maybe I will recommend if you're kind of looking for a horror game to quickly pass the time OR if you scare really easily. Just maybe get it on sale.  Here is hoping Penumbra Black Plague will be scarier.

Penumbra: Overture is the first release from Frictional Games, which went on to make some of the best horror games in history: Amnesia: The Dark Descent and SOMA. Itâs always interesting to go back and see where famous and talented developers got their start, and Penumbra is no exception. Now, I will admit that Iâm not a big fan of horror, or being scared in general, but I played through this game and I can appreciate it for what it is. Penumbra was originally planned to be a trilogy, but after the release of the second chapter, titled Black Plague, the planned third chapter was instead turned into an expansion. I havenât played Black Plague, but Overture stands well on its own.  The game starts with you receiving a letter from the main character, Philip. He urges you not to follow him and ends with an ominous thought, âIf we are lucky, then by the time you receive this, I will be dead. If fate frowns, we all perish.â You play the game through Philipâs eyes, as he himself receives a letter from his supposedly-dead father, and follows its directions to an abandoned WWII mine in northern Greenland. Follow Philip as he delves deeper and deeper into the mine, where almost as soon as he arrives, he realises something is very wrong. What he thought was just an abandoned outpost is instead a twisting maze of tunnels, each section full of weirder and more disturbing revelations than the last.  This is a game that relies not on jump scares and combat, though those do exist. Penumbra is full of what makes Frictionalâs games so truly terrifying: existential horror, and it makes you really uncomfortable in your own skin. Youâll get good insight into Philipâs mind through text overlays on screen of his reaction to events. Cheap but effective. An interesting feature that supports the immersive atmosphere is the physics engine. To open a drawer, you donât just click on it like in other games. You actually click-and-drag the handle. To swing a hammer in self-defense, or to break down a barricade, you donât click or hit a keyboard button. You drag your mouse across the whole screen in the direction you want to swing. This design gives a very heavy, tactile feel to the world youâre in, making you feel much more engaged and connected to the story. Which is critical for horror games. In a brilliant design choice, Philip isnât a soldier, and he doesnât act like it. Combat is difficult, unwieldy, and largely ineffective. Catch sight of a mangy dog, for example, will cause Philipâs breathing to become heavy, and heâll start to panic. You can feel his terror as he prays for the dog to not turn this way, please no, IT SAW ME, RUN! The past few years have seen many games with this conceit, that youâre just an ordinary guy in extraordinary circumstances, but Penumbra was one of the first.  Frictional Games are very well aware that less is more in the horror genre. Youâll read a note about giant spiders, and instead of getting chased down a corridor, fighting your way out, your only path is to crawl into a hole in the floor, hearing scratches and scrapes just out of sight. But you wonât interact with a single spider, not yet anyway. Run across a dog, and as you desperately hide behind a crate, youâll hear its breathing as it sniffs for you. The sound effects are top notch, really deepening the sense of danger. Doors creak as they open, Philipâs breathing and footsteps are loud enough to wake the dead, or at least youâd think so when youâre trying to hide from some unseen flesh-devouring beast. The graphics are a little dated by todayâs standards, but theyâre not too shabby for an indie game from 2007. The game only consists of a 334MB download, so it is understandable that there are only a few textures in the game: wood, stone, metal, and rock, with some slight variations. The lighting is where atmosphere is really made, though. It is almost impossible to see without using either your flashlight (which constantly drains battery) or your glowstick, which covers everything in an unearthly green. Many games would have flickering lights spread all throughout this abandoned mine, but Frictional is smarter than that. Why would there be working lights down here, when no oneâs been here in 30 years?  As you explore deeper and deeper, youâll begin receiving messages from someone calling themselves Red. Your only companion is this odd voice that guides you through the tunnels, the one piece of normalcy in this cave of monsters. You can see similarities to Bioshock in this regard. A minor nitpick I have with the game is something most horror games struggle with. Failure (i.e. death) resets you to your last checkpoint, at which youâll realize you know whatâs coming. So whatever set piece they had intended to terrify you instantly loses its impact. After a while, youâll start playing it like a game, trying to run past the stupid dog and finish your objective, not worrying about dying anymore. The instant death loses meaning, is the instant the gameâs atmosphere gives out.  Without spoiling the ending, let me tell you that the choices you have to make at the end of the game are both horrifying and inevitable. The cliffhanger that the game ends on sets up the sequel, but I do not think it is necessary to play. Itâs scarier if you donât know what happens next.  So Penumbra: Overture is an engaging, immersive game. Even as a wussy non-fan of horror, my curiosity got the better of me and I overcame my fears to explore this mineâs deadly secrets. It was enjoyable, if unnerving. Satisfying, but unsettling. And I suppose thatâs what a horror game should be. Great work, Frictional Games.

At first I thought it was going to be a first-person point-and-click so I got excited. But I soon learned the horrifying truth... that this would be a horror game! Environmental hazards, item puzzles, confusion, darkness and fear of the unknown... I immediately started thinking of jump scares and Amnesia, so it was a relief to learn this was made by the same creators of Amnesia so this would be a high-quality Amnesia clone by people who knew what they were doing. Because they did it before. Several times. If you like atmospheric story-heavy horror games where you run and hide like a little baby because light attracts danger, this will be right up your alley. If you're like me and would rather punch the monsters in the face or at the very least NOT have to cower and run and hide while piecing together the story, you should play Skyrim or Le Chuck's Revenge instead.
Perhaps not as scary as Amnesia, but still contains a creepy atmosphere and the music is sick. Worth playing for fun in a dark room ;)

Another wondeful gaming experience. (TL DR VERSION BELOW!)  Penumbra: Overture is not properly a game as we are used to play, is more like an immersion into deep abyss of horror and mistery.  This is to say you are not buying this game for his gameplay, his longevity or his action. If you played Amnesia, Soma or the other Penumbra you know what I'm meaning. If you don't, well think twice before buying it even if the price is low. Those kind of game are not much appreciated by the average gamer who looks for a couple or more hour of FUN. When you buy Penumbra you want to live a different experience, a journey into mistery and creepy stuff. It's quite short, graphic are still ok in my opinion if you don't mind too much (you don't really have to if you are wishing to play this graphic are the least thing to mind)   When you finish it you feel that feeling of satisfaction as you survived a 7hrs trip into this game. It's something games like Fallout,Skyrim or whatever call of duty or battlefield could never give to you. Even if they might be good games, they are nothing in terms of deepness and peculiarity.   TL DR:  PROS -Atmosphere, deepness, peculiarity, horror. You really are yourself as a normal human being would, trying to escape from a mine, you don't fight unless if really you have to (and you will die trying), you don't have superpower. Only your mind and your notes. That's it.  CONS -Only English language, it's not a problem if you are reading this but there is a lot of stuff to read if you want to understand more the story, and even some dialogue with the only human (?) you 'meet' are quite hard to follow because it's not a simple english. I really had some problems too as is not my mother tongue.

Overture and Black Plague are two halves of the same game. Overture is part 1, Black Plague is part 2. The second part is a direct continuation and has the same game mechanics/gameplay (except a few minor differences) so this review is for both games.   First of all I rate this 9/10. Part 1 has terrible combat and that's the only reason it's not a 10/10. Luckily the devs seemed to realize how bad the combat was and completely axed it in part 2, so like Amnesia you must run from or outwit monsters instead of engaging them.  Overture is primarily a puzzle solver. It's not too scary, but it does have a creepy atmosphere. What I love about Frictional Games is that their puzzles are very sensible, although there were a few here that had me really confused. Part of the problem is that you have to destroy your environment sometimes, but there's no indication which objects are destructble and which aren't- and sometimes you have monsters on your heels, so it's hard to look around and search the environment to figure out what to do before you die.  Black Plague is where the game starts to get really interesting. It has an AMAZING story, and in addition to good puzzles (less environment destroying in this one) the setting is truly horrific. Amnesia didn't scare me, but this game did. It doesn't even use cheap pop-ups, (well a few) instead relying on music/sounds and unsettling atmosphere. Psychological horror at its finest.  The story is intensely engaging. You will care about the friends/family the protagonist (Phillip) encounters in his journey. There are many sad moments. But the true meat of the plot lies in an ancient mystery you will slowly unravel as you discover the many notes, books, and strange artifacts strewn throughout the mining/research facility. The ending is satisfying in that it gives you the answers you seek and doesn't leave you hanging, although I was somewhat disapointed that you appear to be presented with a choice, yet your character can only make one in the end.
Great game with a pretty amazing plot. Can be quite â¥â¥â¥â¥ing terrifying at times, really embodies a good survival horror game.
I really enjoyed all 3 games, although sometimes the direction is vague it's a classic worth a playthrough. It's not Amnesia but a good series none the less.

Warning: don't play it on hard as I did. The game just scales enemy's heath and decrease yours to a 'glass state' (two hits kill). Play it on normal, and you will have a balanced chalenge.  This is a slow pace, first person thriller game. There are some readings, but nothing like a RPG.  The interactivity with objects is nicely done and, despite the limitation of the game's engine, the physics is realistic to the point of believability. For example, you lift, drag, pull objects with movements of your mouse.  The atmosphere transports you to a depressed world, somewhat like the first Silent Hill.  Runs great in Ultrawide (2560 x 1080), Windows 10 (64bit).   A must play to all hardcore single players fans of terror or suspense.

This is going to be a hard review. I wish I could be neutral about it, but due to Steams review mechanics I will have to reach a verdict at the end. Oh boy. Please read carefully, especially my conclusion!  Lets talk about the atmospheric, story-driven experience you are going to get out of this first. Though graphically not top-notch given the year the game was released it sets up a great, intimidating and believable atmosphere with a mysterious touch to it. Great sound assest, brilliant light effects and decent level design regarding maze-like interiors. Aesthetically everything falls into place when you consider the fact that you are   an explorer   going   down into a mine   to find secrets   your father   left behind. The story, while a little bit predictable, is told very well and involves the player in it.  Mechanics. It is Frictional Games' first game which set a milestone in story telling gaming, which is wonderful. Not so wonderful is the fighting system, which is forced upon you   when encountering enemies, like dogs or spiders  . It is not like in Games like Half-Life where you bash your enemies' heads in with your crowbar while still being able to evade their attacks - no! You have to swing your melee weapons with your mouse and you control it directionally, meaning that you can swing either side: left, right, or direct push. Problem is, that your screen locks when you try to swing, so you are unable to move. This is obviously not a good idea and you might think, that it encourages sneaking. And yes, at first that is the case - but soon you are not able to avoid encounters and you will have to brawl your way through, which is frustrating in a great way. This is a big negative, since it is practically forced upon the player and you have almost no way of avoiding it or finding a way around fighting - and you will come across those situations regularly.  Other mechanics work quite well. Puzzle solving is a bit tricky at times given the dated graphics, especially texture quality. For example: You find a key and don't know where to put it? It might be that pixely black mess of a texture on a control panel! This makes it quite complicated and it could use some sort of indicator, but well, it works somehow. Certainly, patience is required.   Conclusion  IF, only if you can withstand a large amount of depressing forced and flawed combat (I guarantee you that you will shut your game off multiple times!) and live for excellent atmosphere in every aspect, I can recommend this game. This game shows you why Amnesia was/is such a big success as THE atmospherically overwhelming and best written game up to this day (haven't played SOMA yet). Play Penumbra and - if you played later games of FG like Amnesia - you will experience an immersive adventure putting you through a relentless environment.  Recommendation? I shouldn't, because it forces those combat sequences on you like crazy. But I have to considering the artistic part of the game, which takes a greater part than combat. If you really have doubts about the ever returning bad combat system, just read up on the plot and continue with the second game without playing this one. That's basically the workaround.

Penumbra Overture is a great little horror game. It is plain to see that it is a predecessor of Amnesia: The Dark Descent. There are many similarities within the imagery, gameplay and storytelling. For Amnesia fans seeking more content, this series is definitely worth playing.   The setting, an underground mine, allows for a certain amount of isolation and otherworldliness. I am not claustrophobic at all and didn't find the envrionments particularly scary, but I can appreciate that it is an eerie setting. I enjoyed the feeling of being deep within the ground.  At times the game reminded me of John Carpenter's The Thing, one of my favorite films.  The game would have benefited from far fewer enemies. They can be easily killed but the controls make it time consuming and frustrating. Killing enemies became repetitive and felt like a chore, but it was a necessary evil... it didn't make any sense to waste time sneaking back and forth repeatedly in the hub environments when the enemies are so easily killed.  The storytelling was very well done. Most information is gathered through found writings. The writings were extremely effective at building the world and adding tension to the game. Generally I was excited to find a new note to read, with a morbid curiosity of what information I would discover.  The controls are somewhat clunky and finicky. For the most part it doesn't affect gameplay because you can explore at your leisure. Perhaps it adds to the fear when you are fumbling around in a hurry.  There are scripted sequences where it becomes a problem. This is because a certain amount of precision is required and the clumsy controls don't allow for that easily. Add to that a healthy dose of guesswork. I was disappointed when I had to replay scripted sequences 4-5 times trial-and-error style. That type of frustration is the fastest way to break immersion and remove all fear from the situation.  There is no manual save and the auto-saves are far apart considering how easy it is to die. I have been spoiled by newer games, but it was really annoying the few times I died and lost a bunch of progress. Minor gripe!  I came to the Penumbra series as a fan of The Dark Descent, looking for a similar horror experience. Overture is obviously not as polished as The Dark Descent but it is well worth playing. I am glad I was able to do a blind playthrough and have another great experience courtesy of Frictional Games.  Replay value is not really there for me. This is only due to the controls and the repetitive enemy encounters. The game itself isn't something I will soon forget. Great ending! I'm looking forward to the next game, Black Plague. From what I hear it's even better than Overture.

Really short, somewhat clumsy controls and not as polished as Amnesia, but still I liked this a lot. I've seen a lot of criticism directed towards this game due to the combat systen. This is a survival horror, it should be difficult to fight back against enemies, and it should make you feel like avoiding them is the best option. This game does that perfectly. The physics in this game are fantastic, the puzzle solving feels very intuitive, and the narrative is gripping. The game doesn't rely on traditional jump scares, instead it utilizes it's environment, the exposition of the story, and the constant fear of what may be following you. This game is honeslty more than worth it's price, and it's a concise game. Well worth playing for any horror fans.

This game is â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥t. I played Amnesia, read that this was the predecessor, but Amnesia is a few order of magnitude above this crap.   The start is enought to make you shake your head - you start by leaving a boat, you go somewhere into the snowy wastelands, you're minutes from freezing to death, but you randomly find a hatch into the relevant mine. You have a hammer in your inventory with which you can, in theory, kill the dog. But swining the hammer is so awful, you can barely smash a crate. As a combat mechanic, is completely and utterly useless. If you can't hide from the dog and you can't fight the dog, the only thing you can di is uninstall.
