â¥â¥â¥â¥ing SERIOUSLY. I mean...SERIOUSLY. I â¥â¥â¥â¥ you not...MOTHER. â¥â¥â¥â¥ING. SERIOUSLY.    I mean, are we not even going to PRETEND that we put any effort into something before we slap it up on Steam these days, even for a measly two bucks? Even if it was FREE, this would barely be worth the effort. Oh, and to save all you pedantic â¥â¥â¥â¥ers the time it would take to type one sentence...the reason it says I only played this for 0.3 hours is because THAT'S HOW â¥â¥â¥â¥ING LONG IT TOOK ME TO PLAY IT. TO THE END. Maybe even reduce that to 0.2 hours once you take into account navigating menus and what-not...   Not that such a thing would necessarily completely and utterly appal me, were those fifteen minutes comprised of almost non-stop 'sheer awesome'. A handful of keys to go through a handful of doors and gates is not, however, my definition of particularly awesome, even if there was one short bit in the game which actually terrified the LIVING â¥â¥â¥â¥ out of me. But alas, I believe it was all bark and no bite, as I never got to see the monster supposedly stalking me.    The game also sports an admittedly unusual and genuinely interesting art style, and the sound is impressively oppressive, but other than that...SHEER AND UNMITIGATED â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥. I won't even bother to mention the quality of the English translations, as frankly, they're far from the worst thing on display here...though suffice it to say, 'I did not expect that he will go crazy' isn't really a sentence.   This, however, IS a sentence: â¥â¥â¥â¥ YOU, MR MAMEDOV. I've been silly enough to buy TWO of your â¥â¥â¥â¥-arse games now. Do us a favour and spend some TIME on the next one, eh? You're not completely talentless, that's clear enough, but my you are one lazy, lazy â¥â¥â¥â¥er. Make your games LONGER, and BETTER. Or failing that, if you're still at the stage where you're learning the ropes, please don't ask people to PAY MONEY for your half-finished 'experiments'.    Better yet, team up with some like-minded people, as good games are rarely made by just one person, least of all some dude named Yuri who still lives in his mother's basement. Surely the guy who made 'Houston, We Have a Problem' lives just up the road from you - and I can't help but notice that his entire catalogue of 'games' has mysteriously vanished from the Steam store altogether - so if you put your heads together you might manage something half-way acceptable.    Hell, I'm a bit of a Hot Chocolate fan...everyone sing along...'I believe in miracles...'  Verdict: 3.5/10.

Key to door simulator.  There isnt any sort of story here really....or at least, it's indistinct due to what I assume is a terrible translation. The actual game looked and sounded cool. There is a monster, but it does nothing. It offers you a morality choice for no apparent reason.  Basically, you just wander around finding keys to unlock doors while reading some terribly translated notes and taking in the admittedly cool looking grisly scenery...and then the game ends by letting you know that you are either cool with being in hell or have escaped hell by being given a second chance, although the game is also not really clear on what you really did. Presumably you killed your family, but one of the notes suggests that your wife actually killed you despite the fact that you killed her (and this is a great example of what a terrible translation can do to your story, lol). Why you would be given a second chance is indistinct. Also, there is a note that states that a monster is sealed in the church crypt with somebody acting as the watcher, and tells the watcher to flee if the monster escapes, lol. Anyway, the story wasnt really something that made any sort of sense. The common thread between the stuff you find was either left out or wasnt thought out well enough to include in the first place.  This actually had the potential to be a pretty cool and creepy game, but in practice, it failed miserably. After 10 or 15 minutes, you will have finished the game and will be left wondering what you had just been doing. You will definitely feel zero compulsion to bother playing a second time to witness the other ending (you have a generic good and bad ending available).  Also, the game is laggy as hell.  I wouldnt really bother unless you are bored and cant decide what to play. Definitely dont pay more than 10 or 20 cents for this one.  9 failed expectations out of 10 (do the math for my rating).

I didn't want to give this game a bad review, I took it with a grain of salt that I shouldn't expect a masterpiece for what, $2? However I'm extremely disappointed in the very brief amount of time I bothered with this game. If I can run Fallout New Vegas smoothly on a high setting then I should have no trouble playing a game with graphics that look like it was made for a ps1 console. I absolutely struggled to do ANYTHING even on the lowest setting. The game was so laggy, so slowly paced and even from the second I pushed play I knew I would be highly unsatisfied when I began to read the nonsensical scrolling text that had not even been proofread or spelled correctly.  Even if it is a low budget Indie game I would expect that for a minimal amount of money the creators would not skimp out on grammar.  I want to say more about it but I can't because I couldn't bring myself to even try to get further in the game. Maybe I'll give it another attempt, it IS only supposedly 20 minutes long, but as far as my initial thoughts on my playthrough? I can't recommend this to anybody.
ALERT! Devs of this game are buying fake reviews!

I just finished this game, and while I'm not a professional critic I am a critical consumer. Having said this I wanted to voice my opinion to aid anyone interested in this title. This game's style in terms of overall concept and creativity is quite good and unique. However I cannot recommend anyone to purchase it. 'My Bones' is incredibly short even for a narrative. I completed it with both alternate conclusions in sixteen minutes. There are many bugs, grammatical errors, and it feels like a student project. (And likely is.)   Again from an artistic stand point I can appreciate what the developer was trying to achieve, but this alone doesn't justify a price tag of any kind. This should be offered as a free experience for the casual and curious. I paid ninety nine cents for this download, and while this amount is inconsequential, it is unmerited.   -A short review, for a short title-

Basically a man killed his own family with an axe and wakes up in a weird place he thinks is hell: you'll take control of him and decide his fate by simply opening gates and doors with the keys you find nearby before being faced with a choice between 'dark' and 'light'. That's pretty much all, the actual game is nothing more than a few areas where you get a key, open a gate/door and move to the next area: it's dull, suffers from low production values and is extremely short.   PROS:   -the few music and audio effects aren't too bad   CONS:   -very little story, nonsensical 'choices' (do you want to leave hell and have a second chance or just stay in it?)  -stumbling English  -poor graphics overall, textures are quite bad even from a medium distance  -dull gameplay, navigate a couple corridors ---> find key ---> open door ---> repeat  -no real horror or tension, it's just empty areas/ corridors with some 'scary' sound effects thrown in every now and then  -annoying loading screens to each area are also preceded by framerate drops  -a bit buggy, in my first playthrough an invisible wall'd persist for a few seconds in front of opened gates: the last area also suffers from graphical glitches  -extremely short, my first playthrough was 10 minutes, the second was 5: no replay value at all   http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=652237858   My Bones is simply lacking as a game, in fact there's not really much of a 'game' here. You walk around, look at uninteresting words/ phrases artificially pasted on walls, find a key and open a door to the next area: sure there's a 'beast' appearing briefly a couple times but it does nothing, it simply stares at you for two seconds and disappears...it also looks rather funny and not menacing at all.  I'd forgive shallow gameplay and pretend this is just a walking simulator if the story was at least interesting but sadly this isn't the case. What's there is either cliched, hard to understand due to the terrible translation or simply makes little sense: it's just vague words accusing you of your deeds or explaining once again you're in hell. When you consider it all the whole plot makes little sense and isn't gripping or surreal enough to engage you in any way. The two endings aren't explained either, why am I given two choices after navigating a few areas? Why'd I even choose the 'bad' one? No idea, no closure, no explanation to anything. The fact this 'ending' happens after 10 to 5 minutes you started playing is also embarassing, I understand this is a 2$ game but that doesn't excuse the sudden and poor way it ends, as if they ran out of ideas or funds and had to wrap things up quickly.  My Bones fails to deliver any interesting gameplay or story nor has any decent content going for it. I can't recommend it at any price nor is it really worth an install if you got it from a bundle like me (unless you want to sell the trading cards).

This game is laggy, boring and overall not a game. Even as a joke game to play with your friends, you won't find any fun in this. WHO PUTS A â¥â¥â¥â¥ING KEY LITERALLY 3 FEET FROM A LOCKED GATE!? WHAT IS EVEN THE POINT?!

Stay away from this badly put together 'game'. I took 15 minutes to beat it, and I still feel it was a huge waste of time.   Pros  - Some cool sound effects (nothing amazing) - the idea for the story is good  Cons  - Broken text, the guy does not even now how separate the words between commas (using the spacebar) - Terrible 'English' - Gameplay consists of getting keys to unlock doors, reading terrible notes and waiting for the next level to load - Choices are a joke

It took just under half an hour to complete and that was with taking time to speak to a friend while playing.  The grammatical errors and spelling mistakes had me in stitches though.   http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=505958934

My Bones is incredibly short indie horror experience. The game can be completed under seven minutes. Unfornately, this horror title is more of a walking simulator. The atmosphere is almost praiseworthy. The soundtrack needs more work; the soundtrack of a video game is an integral aspect of the experience.   Whilst it is highly recommended to avoid purchasing this game, if one were tempted to buy it wait for a sale on the game. It is undoubtedly not worth the full price.   A brillant alternative to this game is Kholat; Kholat is story rich, good horror atmosphere and stunning detail.

Check my playtime.......yes, it is that short  Coding is horrible, lighting is messed up, the english is a hilarious travesty and the selection of game-engine to operate the game was horrible. There is only one positive thing about it and that is the dungeon section with the pentagram. The choral music there is siiiiick and reminded me of Georgy Ligeti's music. That section was also quite fair  Seriously, i know in my heart by both experience and analysis..........that indie debuts can be thousand times better So you, the creator of this game, please remember im only attacking the game here, not you as a person. Just poor. Which is a shame as the screenshots and premise intrigued me. I wanted to enjoy this but the term 'budget' is an insult to every other budget game out there. The game just seems so rushed. It's like they started with some great ideas and then ran out of time and stitched the fragments together. Special note has to be given to the most gamebreaking translation work I've ever seen. It was somewhat more forgivable when it was scrolling text detailing the protagonists thoughts but when it's your dead family's scrawled notes on the wall it just becomes laughable.  I encountered no enemies in the game, though I did notice in another review that there apparently is one somewhere. Though given the main character's glacial plod and lack of attack move, I'm not sure what I could have done if I had.  The game was exceptionally short (about a dozen minutes, start to end, without rushing), though given the quality it was a small mercy. There was some amount of potential showing in the underground level where tension was starting to be built. Then all of a sudden, it stops, there's no payoff and the game ham-fistedly bungles you into the ending.  Avoid.

scariest part about the game is the grammar i swear, it sounds like it was written by a 6 year old in vietnam. check my play time. that's 2 full play throughs, first time exploring everything and giving it a chance, the second time a speed run just so i could see what the other ending was.  seriously, don't bother, really laggy, mildly 3spoopy5me sounds/music, no plot to speak of, no character development, no difficulty whatsoever, really linear. you can even technically make it through without using all the keys.  they keep mentioning some beast being on the loose, and if you look through its cage you can see a fuzzy picture of what appears to be a butchered pig for a second or less. much scared, so intrigued.  would be better if there was actually something to run from, or if the developer hired someone to proofread, seriously. how do you expect to have a story driven game that is just unreadable.  oh, and no trading cards.

Find a key here, open a door, find a key there, open a door, lots and lots of keys. The sound effects are ok I suppose but everything else is somewhere between boring and just god awful. Then for no reason the game ends after 15 mins or so and I just don't know what it was all about. Paid 30p in the sale. Save your money and give it to the homeless instead.

Positives:  - 'It is a short but very interesting horror' + for honest developer (completed this game in 15 minutes)  Negatives:  - So ridiculously short it's not even funny - Terrible grammar - 'Very intresting horror'. No, no, no, no, no.... (read further down) - FPS drops down whenever I walk up to a corpse or a checkpoint for some reason - 100% key quests - No creativity or originality at all   Story:  'Very intresting horror'. I found some text in a couple of tombes and found one note with zero character development. That's it. Not to mention it's a clichÃ© 'I killed my family, now I have to go through hell for it' type of story, and you call that 'very intresting'?  Gameplay:  100% key quests, basic gameplay mechanics and zero replay value. Some scary moments, but besides that, the gameplay is nothing worth mentioning.   Conclusion:  I completed this game in 15 minutes, so at least I'm giving the developer a plus for honesty, but besides that, this game is not worth your money. It's a demo you have to pay for basically with no creativity whatsoever.  2/10 - Very bad, would demand a refund again

Pros: +Some parts are genuinely creepy. The scenery is interesting and there's some decent use of lighting in places.  Cons: -Extremely short length (10-15 mins for a playthrough) -Very poor use of written English that breaks immersion -There's a flashlight, but the game feels creepier without using it. Unfortunately the flashlight is very bright, and is needed to find some things in the dark -The 'evil' ending is a bit nonsensical. The protagonist recognizes his own grave, and then his car won't start. Thus, he is in hell. -A subplot seems to have been abandoned (there is no monster in the underground hallways) -Main gameplay consists of walking around and finding a handful of keys to unlock doors. No interaction with other characters or objects
- 15 minutes long - no action what so ever - terrible graphic - bad story telling - lots of commas - unbelievable long loading screens  no fun or scares experienced, dont buy this game.

My Bones  plays with a very interesting notion of choosing between the eternal bliss of forgiveness, or the burden of repeated purgatory. However, the game itself has no substance, and doesn't allow players to fully become immersed to the threatening ambiance.   The gameplay is slow, linear, and extremely choppy that at times I thought my PC was about to crash. It is also laughably short and riddled with grammatical errors in the very little text provided. The only real positive note within  My Bones  is the moody sounds that kept me interested for the 10 minutes it took me to finish the game twice (for the sake of both endings).  The only reason anyone should ever check out this game is to maybe have a friend who is not a gamer and scares easy try it out. But there's better options to do that with other .50 titles on Steam already, so...pass.

Okay, so, seeing as I only spent 2$ on this game I wasn't expecting much...and that's what I got, not much.   The only part of this game that even came close to becoming a horror genre was the audio for me, it gets a little intense in a single part of the game then it ends. It's very short but that is a given, but, man, is it SHORT. I finished both routes in less than 40 minutes and that is only most likely because I spent some time looking at the surroundings.   It's straight forward and the hidden objects (only keys) are very easily found. I was expecting a bit more information on the storyline, but you get simple short scripts at the beginning and end while you are left to piece together the rest. Not to mention you can tell it wasn't a native english speaker who pieced together the words for you to read. Normally this wouldn't bother me, but I feel this should have been cared for a little better in a game that really all you should expect from is a short story. However, low budget is low budget.  Now, while I was disappointed, I was a bit surprised at the surroundings and honestly the textures and graphics aren't even too terrible.   Breakdown: I wouldn't buy it again, but if you feel like playing a VERY short totally unintersting (to me, at least) game with decent graphics...go for it.

Like walking with heavily compressed sound and bad graphics. Want a 10 minute horror game about a dude who was dead but now is not dead but is still dead. Uh...okay, this is probably the most uninteresting, uninspired, amateurishly slapped together 'game' I have ever 'played'.   Seriously. 'My Bones' feels like it has been clicked together by a 13-year old using some level construction kit. There are only 3 environments (Graveyard, Basement, Exit), possible interactions with your surroundings merely consist of crawling around gathering keys (while walking speed is incredibly slow) and using your flashlight... But hey, you can jump, too! But you only need to do so one or two times in the whole game (which can be completed in 15min if you take your time looking at stuff) So, let me sum the plot up for you:   #SPOILERS! (lol....)  -Wake up at graveyard, collect keys, go to church, walk up to some trapdoor, then -SHAZAM!- you are in the basement. -Walk around in basement, collect keys, open door then -SHAZAM!- little intersection with nonsense text (it doesn't deserve being called 'story', really...) -Walk forward -SHAZAM!- you are at the exit. -THE END.  Alright, I use the term 'SHAZAM' for a reason.  You basically just walk up to an invisible event trigger, then without notice the game starts preloading some assets for new surroundings (which takes up so many resources that the game starts stuttering, even on high-end hardware) and you are magically warped into a new environment. Shazam...  The whole game is flooded with spelling errors. I hate that. It just underlines how poorly done it is...   To be fair, audio is okay! At least with no headphones on...  Don't be fooled by the affordable price, 'My Bones' is not even close to being an Indie title (except you define 'Indie' as 'Puking on the keyboard and publishing the resulting code on Steam'), it's not even a Demo. It's just a joke I can't laugh at. Sorry. I just feel ripped off when I'm asked to pay real money for stuff that even I could have done better than the one who created it.  (I know I'm being a real meanie here, but I'm sick and tired of this kind of crappy products polluting the Steam market and degrading the 'Indie' genre. At least have your mum spellcheck your games if you really have to throw them at people!)  Sigh....

Awful. I really love indie horror, but this was appalling. The grammar and spelling was terrible, the gameplay was jerky, the story line was incomplete and cliche. Only enjoyable moment was turning around to find that the empty room I had been in was now full of corpses.

It took me roughly 25 minutes to beat this game twice, to see both endings and all the little touches in between. The rest of the time was waiting for card drops. It's a decent enough short story that really didn't translate into game too well. It feels like there were a lot of details in the creator's head that made cameos in the game and never actually got to exist. 'The Beast' at least gets to beat on a door for a second before the game clumsily suggests that you are the most evil thing in the room. Or you're the beast. Not sure, since all it does is make bodies appear when you stand near its cage. Also, the game suffers heavily from the author's non-fluent-English as the entire game is story-driven and all in written text.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zV9BvqjiwTA  My Bones is a short indie horror game brought to us by publisher/developer Infernal Dream, the same company that has provided such titles as VERGE:lost chapter, White Mirror, and Lost Souls. Sticking with its trademark, My Bones is made in Game Guru, and features overly-long loading screens when transitioning from one area to the next.  Sticking with the format of the other games from the developer's library, this title also features extremely poor optimization and horrid framerates. Even on my mid-high end rig, I saw no better rates than 44 FPS, and as little as 14 in some points. There is zero direction, and absolutely nothing that tells you about the control scheme of the game; with the exception of pressing E to pick up keys and open doors.  Yes, My Bones is a key finding simulator... a very short, horrendously optimized one. I spent most of the game wandering around in the dark because I had no idea that you apparently have a flashlight. There's supposedly an evil piggie in the second level, but I'd only heard it oink once, and it was no threat at all; therefore I don't believe that you can actually die. There are two endings, one good and one evil, but I'm uncertain as to why you would put yourself through the pain of this game more than once, just to see an alternate, mostly text-based ending.  I could also point out the poorly written aspect of this game, but I really hate doing that to developers who obviously do not have English as a first language. Yes, the grammar and punctuation is bad, but I will say at least the developer tried. I've seen many other developers stop trying to translate their games into English because of this type of criticism. A better proof reader, or translator, would help a lot in this scenario, but the plot points still come across just fine.  It confuses me as to how My Bones has a Very Positive and Mostly Positive rating on Steam, and how there are so few negative reviews on this game. Have people become so willfully accepting of badly optimized, poorly written, key finding simulators masquerading as horror games? This title is nothing short of horrible, and I would go as far to say as it's worse than VERGE:lost chapter, just with fewer loading screens... because it's significantly shorter. I got this title on sale for $0.65 CAD, and I honestly regret it. Stay away, even when it's on sale. Play Fingerbones instead... not only is it a hundred times better than this game, it's also free.   Rating:  0.5/5.0  - Abysmal, avoid it like the plague.

'My Bones' is an interesting, very short, atmospheric narrative - nothing more.  =====  CONS:   - Lack of story: There's a story here, but, its not fleshed out enough. It's cliched and lacks any engaging hook to pull the player in.   - Lack of puzzles/challenges/obstacles: Find a key, open a door. ...That's the difficulty level. It wouldn't necessarily be a bad thing, but it really feels like its only here to slow the pace and pad the game, so as to give the illusion of more gameplay. I would consider that a negative.  - General lack of content: Just as stated. There's really not much, at all, to do.  - Abrupt ending(s): Just as stated. They just kind of... end.   - Broken English: I feel this game would have faired better had it been released in either the developer's native tongue only, or with the option to play in a (broken) English mode. Its understandable if one's main dialect is used in a game, as they want to share, but it really detracts from the overall experience having it solely in a language that is clearly not a primary one. Its not terrible, but it helps to break immersion, and some word choices are so wrong that they completely muddle the intended meaning.  - Transitions: They are abrupt, and just 'bonk' you into a new area. There's no real transition. Example: Walking through a dungeon-like area, go through a door into a hallway; loading screen -> Now you're outside in a field, somehow. Very confusing... not even a portal or two to explain the jump?    NEUTRAL  -/+: Very short: The game itself takes less than 10 minutes to play through. That's not necessarily a positive, nor is it a negative. Games like 'The Graveyard' are nice, short titles that give a feeling, and deliver it very well. Other times, however, short can mean 'lacking content'. This kind of falls into the middle, as further highlighted in my 'PROS' section.    PROS:  + Very atmospheric: The atmosphere is very unsettling. The developer knew what they wanted to share as far as mood, and really made it clear.   + Visuals: The lighting, and overall ambiance of the game was just fine. It looked good, was detailed enough to prove that they put time into design, and was obviously planned, as opposed to slapped together like in some indie titles. Good job on that front~  + Audio: The audio files used were well placed, and fit the game very well. There were no tacky noises, nor were there any overly used ones either; they didn't milk them. They were well placed and added to the overall 'setting' that was in place.    =====  Would I recommend 'My Bones'? Well.. sadly, not.   ..Not for money, anyways.  As a free to play game, I would definitely recommend one to give it a go for interests sake.  I am a strong advocate for Indie developers making games and trying to tell a story.   This game, however... doesn't feel finished.  It feels... weak, with a promise that doesn't deliver.  And now, I think I'll go and rest my own bones for the night~ Pass.

This brand-spanking-new horror game was apparently made on some program called GameGuru ('the easy game maker'). It proudly tells me this on the menu screen. And I have to say, on the strength of this product, should I ever decide to join the glut of people currently making cheap-arsed, â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ horror product in their bedrooms...I might make it a point to avoid GameGuru like the plague. I also might not opt to make and release a game, especially for money, until I confirm that I: a. Have some actual talent making games, and b. Have some remotely worthwhile ideas to fill said game with. Luckily for all of us, Mamedov Yuriy has no such hesitations. He/she/they have made a game, and while it starts promisingly enough in the first few minutes - in which you run down a dirt track through some admittedly lovely scenery - it's all pretty much downhill once you actually reach a large, spooky, asylum-like building and step inside.    In VERGE:Lost chapter - that's precisely how it's written, so for reasons of aesthetic purity, I shall keep it that way - you play a small, kangaroo-like creature (a wallaby, perhaps?) who hops along the corridors of said spooky building, goes through lots of doors, and triggers an excruciatingly long load screen approximately once every thirty-seven seconds. That's when you are not enduring excruciatingly long text screens which, in addition to scrolling by at the speed of darkness, CANNOT BE SKIPPED, at least as best as I can tell. Oh, and did I mention that you CANNOT SAVE at any point of the game, be it manually or by way of predetermined checkpoints...in spite of the fact that you'll basically be requiring a 'primal scream break' every ten minutes or so, lest you put a FIST THROUGH YOUR COMPUTER SCREEN?!    Now, none of this is to say that there's absolutely NO redeeming features to this game. Some of the sound is actually rather effective - emphasis on the word SOME - and some - again, SOME - of the graphics aren't too bad (well, some of the outdoor graphics anyway; the interiors are pretty much uniformly â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥). Other than that, the painfully slow and vertigo-inducing movement basically led me to pack this one in before I'd even so much as laid eyes on a monster, though a quick glance at the trailer on the Store page assures me that I didn't miss out on much.    Y'know, when I was a young'un, I wasted an awful lot of my time and money watching almost every â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥, low-budget horror movie I could lay my hands on. Nowadays, I'm relieved to report that I only waste similar amounts of time and money playing every â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥, low-budget horror GAME I can lay my hands on. Hey...waitaminute...th-that's not any kind of PROGRESS, is it? God preserve me...WHAT AM I DOING WITH MY LIFE?!  Verdict: 2.5/10.

I just finished this game, and while I'm not a professional critic I am a critical consumer. Having said this I wanted to voice my opinion to aid anyone interested in this title. I cannot recommend anyone to purchase it. 'VERGE' is incredibly short just as the previous game 'My Bones' I played from this developer. I completed it with both alternate conclusions in maybe fifteen minutes. Although there are not as many bugs and grammatical errors. The 'Demon' does actually work in this game.  Again from an artistic stand point I can appreciate what the developer was trying to achieve, but this alone doesn't justify a price tag of any kind. This should be offered as a free experience for the casual and curious. I paid ninety nine cents for this download, and while this amount is inconsequential, it is unmerited. Features:   -Multiple endings (best ending is idling to get your card drops) -High quality graphics (A sight to see) -Tense atmosphere of fear (If you fear boredom then yes... this game will be quite frightening) -No cheap jump scares (Not anything really) -High quality audio support. (Deaf people rejoice) -Simple but enjoyable gameplay. (No gameplay that's enjoyable)  One of those games that even if they paid you to play would be considered a horrible waste of time.

Your truck breaks down on a rural road, what seems to be in the middle of no where. Heavy rain starts to pour down and you find yourself seeking shelter. This is how VERGE:Lost chapter, the second title from indie developer M. Yuriy, opens. Let it be said now that if you intend on playing this game, prepare for some incredibly long loading screens that happen quite often. One complete playthrough for me had 8 load screens, which lasted between 30-60 seconds each.  The game starts off with a truly laughable rain effect that does anything but set the mood for terror. It's simply a couple of transparent JPG images looped to create the appearance of rain. The rest of the graphics are decent enough, though if you want to get the better experience remember to press ESC and go into the settings to set them to high; the game automatically runs on medium by default, which is much less impressive. There are only a couple of areas that have any real tension to them, but they last so briefly that it's all over before it actually began.  Whatever scare factor and terror potential that VERGE: Lost chapter houses is completely obliterated by the unreasonable load times. There's nothing quite like sitting around, picking your nails for upwards of a minute every 2-3 minutes. Just as a rough estimate of how often this occurs, I beat the game in 30 minutes; during that time I experienced 8 load screens. That means on average, every 3.75 minutes I came to a standstill at a load screen, and out of the time I spent playing the game, roughly 5-6 minutes was dedicated to load times. That, ladies and gentlemen, is worse than the Playstation 1 era.  Overall, VERGE: Lost chapter isn't anything special. You can choose from two different endings, but neither of them are anything to write home about. The 'good' ending even has a massive plot hole in it. It's definitely not worth sitting through the loading screens again to go back for the other ending, either; just YouTube it. Without these awful sequences, the game might've stood a fair chance, but since they won't be getting patched out or fixed up, completely avoid this mess.   Rating:  0.5/5.0  - Abysmal, avoid it like the plague.

Battle through two empty mazes of storage tanks! Flee from a bald woman! Go to clown prison! If that sounds fun in even a tastelessly terrible way then I have failed to save you from VERGE's budget clutches and that will rest forever on my head.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PjeZcLE7o1Y

2/10  Being a fan of horror games and someone who likes to support small developers - and also keeping in mind this game was made with GameGuru -, I really wanted to come here and recommend this game.  Unfortunately, I can't.  The rain sound effect right at the beginning loops in such a way that you can tell when it loops, as there's a fraction of a second where the sound pauses. The loading screens take WAY too long to load and it completely breaks the game's immersion.  But the game's biggest flaw is that it just... Lacks content. It's incredibly short and it really has nothing to it. No compelling story, no challenge level, no puzzles, nothing. You really just find keys to doors, avoid some few and incredibly easy to avoid hazards and that's it. Also, your actions don't affect the ending, because you literally get to a part where it says 'choose your end'.  Here's the story on how I saw both endings the game has in less than an hour, and I'll keep it spoiler-free: I started the game, got to a part where you have to choose three paths (one of which leads to a locked door). I picked the left path, got stuck in a place that seemed to be a labyrinth of some sort. Couldn't find anything else or no exit so I started over and picked the path forward. After the door I went through on that path, the game gave me more story, so that seemed to be the 'correct path'. After that I was in place where I had to get a key, then get past a hazard, then get to a place where I had to get another key. After I opened the door with that key, for some reason I had to constantly jump towards the open door because the game wouldn't let me in. Then I got to the 'choose your end' part and once more I had to constantly jump through the open door of the ending I chose. Saw the ending, played the game again, didn't get stuck in the doors this time, chose the other ending, got to another area with a hazard to avoid, saw the other ending and done.  And none of the endings explain anything about the story.  I'm not going to say the developer of this game doesn't deserve your money - everyone has to start somewhere and I believe people can learn from their mistakes. However, other than supporting a small developer, I really cannot see any other reason to buy this game at all. Even for the incredibly low price the game has.

I should have known after playing My Bones that this would be terrible but I seem to be a glutton for punishment. I thought maybe, just maybe the developer would have built on the initial game which showed some promise under the layers of terrible design choices. At least this time round, whilst still terrible, the text in the notes lying around is at least on a par with a 12 year old text messages, as opposed to the gobbledegook of My Bones. Good luck trying to find all of it. For some reason the developer thought it would be a good idea to put the writing literally on the walls, only the walls were white and the text was a slightly brighter shade of white. But no matter as it's not worth hunting down, the story makes absolutely no sense. Something about an asylum and an experiment involving children and how one of them becomes superpowered and then rages out of control Then there are clowns for some reason. Technical flaws are abundant. The game lags so hard and is so badly optimised, yet still looks like absolute crap for this day and age. Then there's the door issue, which is seemingly the only thing you can interact with in this game. You open the door, it swings wide open, but you can't cross the threshold until the door has completed its opening animation which takes several seconds too long. Absolutely ridiculous, and the developer thought the best way to draw attention to this was to throw a few doors in during the game's only chase sequence. It's beyond laughable. Then there's an odd 'choose your ending' thing at the very end for some bizarre reason, which was basically about making a choice between a cozy bed or an electric chair watched over by an ominous looking clown. None of this game made any sense whatsoever. And at the end, spoiler alert, and this seemed like the developer was actually just trying to insult your intelligence, as if playing the game wasn't enough of a torture, but in the ending epilgoue text, it talks about how after you escape from the asylum you run to your car and drive away as fast as possible. The only reason you wandered into the asylum in the first place was because your car broke down!!! Avoid like the plague.

DreadOut: Keepers of the Dark originally was meant as a DLC for the original DreadOut game, but eventually surfaced as a standalone title.  Unfortunately, Keepers of the Dark does not have much to offer in its own right - you start in a mirror world of sorts that acts as a travel hub. From there, you can delve into eight different worlds, most of which will seem eerily similiar - not to the least because the better part of the terrain is copied from previous DreadOut levels!  The new ghosts presented in Keepers of the Dark are interesting in their own right - there's anything from haunted dolls to spectral horsemen (or horsewomen, rather) to insane canibals. Sadly, the piecemeal type of presentation which KotD uses means that each of these ghosts only has a minimal story behind it, and what little information the entries of the 'Ghostpedia' offer usually are presented in semi-broken English.  In truth, I think KotD makes one fatal mistake: Horror games, in general, rely on their atmosphere. You never know what's going to hit you, when it's going to hit you, and if it's going to hit you at all. Sadly, KotD does hardly build up any atmosphere at all - if you've played the original game, you already know most of the levels, and the new ghosts introduced in this spinoff only are scary until you understand the basic tactic needed to banish them. To be entirely honest, the ghosthunt gets tedious rather quickly, not to the least because you know that you need to banish a certain number of ghosts per level.  Coupled with the rather short playtime (aprox. 3-5 hours), DreadOut: Keepers of the Dark may perhaps be worth its relatively low price, but not necessarily your time - there are many better horror games to spend your time with.

I really wanted to like this one. The first DreadOut isn't a masterpiece by any means, but it's a lo-fi game with lots of souls to it, and I truly enjoyed it, enough to 100%. Sure enough, I wasted no time in getting KotD and... well, it doesn't measure up to a bar that was kinda low to begin with.  KotD is pretty much just a Boss Rush type thing, with eight different areas, each with one or two bosses, and an item fetch puzzle or two to deal with; problem is, combat certainly wasn't the first game's strong suit, and pretty much all you'll get here is more combat. The boss designs are truly nice and show the creative capabilities of the devs, but that's about all the praise I can give. Pretty much all but one of them boil down to 'back away while taking pictures' and even that isn't particularly fun, as bosses tend to have movesets wildly incompatible with your slow character and stunlock you with annoying frequency.  All but two of the stages are recycled from the base game (with small changes at times, yeah, but still the same areas), so even exploring is off the table. The game has some nice set pieces, but even then they're badly executed - having a ghost girl count down to chasing you is legitimately spooky at first... and not very much on the fourth or fifth time it happens. The story is pretty much nonexistent and/or vague to the point of meaning nothing at all. Seriously, if there was any useful plot to be gleaned, I have no idea what it is.  To sum, good bosses with bad combat, barely any new areas to see, annoying gimmicks and backtracking and just about no development of the story. Not AWFUL for the price, but it's something I wish I had watched on Youtube instead. I'll be waiting for a new game from these devs, though, as I still have faith in them.

Good thing - Keepers of the Dark at least tries to be a good game, unlike the original DreadOut. Bad thing is - it usually fails miserably at it.  It tries to not be a linear spoop-fest of jumpscares, like the original game was, instead trying to focus on the whatever basic mechanics the game has and trying to get the most of them. As such, it now instead consists of a hub-world and several short maps-levels, which can be visited and revisited in any order, with each of them trying to have a good interesting gimmick and main puzzle or puzzles to it.  With mechanics as basic as before, it's amazing just how much more varied and creative the game feels, with each ghost and each world trying to be something unique.  They are not, of course. And not just because all but 3 maps are from the original game, and new maps are terrible. Simply because most cases still simply devolve into stupid unbalanced glitchy damage races, with some things working incorrectly or not working, and some things being just pure bs in terms of what they demand of the player. Oh and all the story and tone things are still complete nonsense. At least, more visually interesting thing were created this time.  In the end, Keepers is both an example that perhaps someday these developers could do something good. And that, 'that some day' will not be anytime soon.

Having downvoted the original DreadOut i was hoping for a better experience with the second game but sadly it wasn't...  I tried to play the game normally and seriously at first but straight from the start i got screwed over by a bug, normally the game starts as if you died and you have to go to the light, i didn't know that when starting and for some reason i didn't get that part and went straight to the hall with all the doors.. Doesn't sound like a big deal but none of the doors brought me to another level, they just opened and i could walk into the little rooms with red walls doing nothing. Already thinking that this was a 'puzzle' i got really annoyed and wanted to stop playing.  Figuring out that it was a bug i went on and gave it another chance, i did the doors in order starting with room 101 where i got greeted with a small stage with little amount of enemies and a boss to finish it off, annoying part 1, the boss got me stun locked in my hit animation for a couple of times which made me die in a frustrating way (the plus side of this game is when you respawn damage dealt stays so you can just keep on going). Door 102, i see mannequins and they trigger my glitch in the camera but it doesn't do anything so i stopped bothering with them not expecting that one of them is a bit different and triggers a chase, instead i find a pretty lady on the second floor that i couldn't kill.. again, annoying because i lacked the information knowing what to do, comparable to the first game. These annoyances gave me a sick feeling and i couldn't play anymore it was anything but enjoyable.   Couple of hours later i decided to take it less seriously 'cause i wanted to finish the game, i bought it and really wanted to play it so i'll make the most of it. I started playing again, took a guide with me to make everything faster and enjoyable and had a stream on my other monitor so i have something enjoyable to follow as well.   Knowing what to do and not wondering if enemies are immortal or not kept me in a flow to get through each room while sometimes even enjoying the game, there are a couple of enemies which are like sidequests were you need to collect items to make them weaker or collect parts of a picture to help a harmless boy. The variety in bosses is enjoyable were for example one of them is music related where you can't fight but you have to dodge the enemies untill the song ends (i read many complaints about this one being hard but i got it first try..) but beware of getting hit and stun locked for 3 hits in a row. Another boss only appears when you collect certain bodyparts shattered around the map where there's a hide and seek mission with a little girl and one of the coolest bosses is optional and the one i talked about before, the pretty lady in room 106, easier to beat if you collect needles found in stages and while fighting her she transforms and gets uglier.   Those are the things i liked but they don't make this game a recommendation for me, the fighting is messed up because you keep on falling down when hit which causes situations where you get stuck for 3-4 hits, the story itself isn't that interesting except for the small backstories of the enemies. Some enemies take a bit too long to take down and aren't challenging either which causes a small feeling of being a 'grind'.  It's a short game (3+ hours) for a low price but i needed a guide and distractions to enjoy it for a decent amount and that's not thumbs up worthy for me. I am aware that using a guide is a bit lame but i'd rather use it and finish the game and respect it for what it is than just dropping it and not giving it a proper chance.

It runs badly, is written terribly, is voice-acted still worse than that, has awful PS2-era textures and animations, and noticibly repetative audio looping. Worst of all, all aspects of it are explained so poorly that I had to look up most of how to play online, and even then it didn't make any sense. I don't just mean the lore (Why would a ghost be afraid of a camera phone?), but the characters and their motivations were also gibberish. The thirtieth time an old woman ghost attacks with the same animation and shrill noise, it isn't scary. It's annoying. When you resume the game from the death area, and within a second you're already attacked again while trapped in a corner, it's bad pacing. I have genuinely zero ideas how this isn't getting savaged by reviews. It's truly abysmal in every way.

A promising aspiration of the horror genre that ultimately ends in hair-ripping frustration due to oversights in puzzle design. This game surprised me for its hilarious, loveable dialogue, cute characters and well thought-out puzzles up until the timed puzzle, which I'll get into later.  You play Gwen, who describes herself as a tomboy, who is in love with another girl called Flora. But this game isn't your typical love story or yuri, as the amusing ArKun villain is introduced, sets the tone for the rest of the game. You're now on a journey to save your girlfriend by going through very creative areas, set pieces, changes of pace and atmosphere at the click of a finger, and puzzle designs that took me back to the days of the old PlayStation 2 survival horror games such as Silent Hill 2, 3 and 4. The puzzle involving the animal heads was genuinely well-made, perhaps one of the best puzzles I've experienced in a horror game since Silent Hill 4.  The hand-drawn art is awesome, it fits the aesthetics of the game and is always a pleasure to look at. However, I would have preferred better transition effects from sprite-to-artwork, such as screen fades or something. Also, the scene near the beginning of the game where Flora is looking out over the cliff could have been enhanced with her hair blowing in the wind, to give it a dramatic effect. This also ties in with how much this game feels like a JRPG despite it being made by an American. As mentioned, the dialogue is surprisingly filled with comedic value - which doesn't detract from the game's enjoyment - but adds to it as it supports the style the game is aiming to achieve. You have lots of different characters, whom I all love, some have their own artwork which gives them even more character through visual narrative.  For a free game this is amazing, there is so much variety in this short-packed adventure, such as the Sloppy Joes, dark atmosphere of the underground crypts, to your everyday Highschool life. However, and this is where I can't recommend this game, is one of the final puzzles in this game. It is the segment that you dive into a lava pit with a timer and have to escape by solving the chemical puzzle, then traversing through the maze-like structure to avoid the lava, then become swarmed by double digit Sloppy Joes (who are the enemies in this game). This is incredibly frustrating, it feels too forced and pressuring to have this come out of nowhere, and it will try your patience as a human being. You either don't have enough time to finish this segment, don't have enough health to beat it due to forced damage, either too many Sloppy Joes swarm you at once, or the horribly unforgiving checkpoint system will make you want to jump our your window. A recent patch was deployed which was suppose to alleviate this infuriating design; but changed little to nothing. So if you're reading this and want to play this, be warned this puzzle will test you.  That said, for owners of Yai Gamesworks' previous game: Close Your Eyes, there is an awesome throwback moment to it, which I really loved and found funny. I won't spoil, but you'll get a giggle out of it for sure.  I can't recommend this game, however, because the instant rise of difficulty killed the game's tone, pacing and comedy value it had going for it. This kind of frustration and experimental puzzle design doesn't always work, and when it does it's usually added in a type of game that has this kind of trial and error persistent in its design. The Souls games, for example, is a mainstream series that glorifies this structured gameplay style. But in an adventure game such as this, where its value comes from the story and puzzles, stopping the player from continuing due to its own design is this game's only downfall. The developer clearly knows what they are doing in this game and, can for a fact, make good puzzles and atmospheric set pieces, but experimenting on abnormal design tradition to further the progression of what is a light comedy, adventurous game is not a mix that bodes well together. Perhaps a future patch can fix this, but I'm not willing to put up with furious design choices out of nowhere, especially after the disaster of a game that is NightCry. But with Take the Dream IX, there is clearly hope and light at the end of the tunnel that Yai Gameworks knows how to make great games.  And no, there is no Take the Dream I-VIII.

I'll try to make this short.  It's about a girl, Gwen, who has a girlfriend, Flora, but one day she's kidnapped. You play as Gwen and you try to save your girlfriend. However, you will find some things about yourself while you travel.   Graphics:  They're OK. Its environments are cute especially those of the town, however, they're just like your typical based RPGMaker game. Some assets in some stages don't fit very well but I think this is the intention, so I don't have any complain about it.  Difficulty and puzzles:  You better have a paper on hand, but you will pass them without problems. Some stages have a time limit, some others make you play hide-and-seek.  Length:  Quite short, but it isn't a problem. If you want to play a short game as a form of relax, this one works.  Replay value:  There isn't.  Story and characters:  No opinion, I'm not the kind of person who ponders over about it: I like it or I don't, that's it. Basically I don't have any complain about it, but I can't say it is my favourite thing either. I can't *see* all about the story and characters though, because this reason I'll explain later on.  Price:  It's free.  So far, I would recommend it -particularly because it is free- but I've reported an error two weeks ago and I didn't receive any response, then, basically, it breaks the game and it doesn't let you to continue, thus I can't finish this game. Logically, I can't recommend a game I can't finish even less when it is a russian roulette, you either get this error or not. Once I'm able to finish this game, I'll change my review (or I don't, depending if I end liking this game or not).

I would not recomend this game as-is, but I really hope the game designer continues to work on it; there is potential here.  For a game about how desperately one may cling to love, this game as it is now feels simply devoid of heart and meaning. Its silly use of tropes and unprofessional sounds/voices really take you out of the story. I hope the designer keeps trying, because there is a balance between meaningful and fun that can be struck here, and I think some more editing, tweaking, re-scripting the lines, and re-recording the voices would help make this an unforgettable jaunty adventure with a dark twist.

4/10 The presentation was solid; many of the graphical choices added to the creepy atmosphere and overall the sound design was solid. The puzzles and challenges are fun but are too few. The story really holds the game back, I appreciate what the developer was trying to accomplish, making attempts to mess with the player's head. But mind-bending games only work if the early-game confusion is balanced out either by endgame understanding, or a very clear theme and message. This game offers neither, and when I finished I felt the game was too short and did not work hard enough to explain what was happening.
the dev had made better game 'close your eyes' but the atmosphere in this game is inconsistent...

Honestly, I was really excited to see another game from the creator/producer of 'Close your eyes'.  In the beginning of the game the idea of mixing different story lines was amazing and the dark and creepy atmosfere was perfect. However, the main story and the developing of the characters was horribly awful and sloppy. I wasn't given the chance to really see the relationship between Gwen and all the other four characters presented to us (Kayto, Vera, Luna and I don't even remember the last one). So all the dialogue between them end up being pointless melodrama that only got in the way to the game.  Nothing was really explained at the end. Also, what was the point of starting the game with the story of a Goddess and a Demon King and a bunch of magic stones if this will be barely used in the game? Really, it was really annoying.  ----SPOILER ALERT---- Also, finishing with 'it was only a dream' made me feel like that were some 2 wasted hours that I could have used to something more fun and productive.   ---END OF SPOILER ALERT---  The game would be ok, if it wasn't for this horribly lazy storytelling

Pitiful berry gathering simulator where the first night unleashes a plague of undead who you will spend the rest of the game fruitlessly trying to outrun while waving lumps of wood around in front of your face, attempting to build a wall.   No base that you construct will ever be as effective at stopping the zombies as clambering up one of the game's many pre-built lookout posts or just hiding inside one of the houses while the terrible AI pathing runs thirty of the idiots directly at whatever wall you're facing.  Don't.   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UbDe0gr113o

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JN9-0JfRIR0&feature=youtu.be   This is just a pixelated map thrown together with collectibles and randomly spanning enemies.  The game obviously tries to imitate superior games such as Minecraft or The Forest, but is plagued by technical issues and offers nothing original in return.  Here are some issues I have with this game:  - There's no tutorial: the game only tells you to press 'F' to pick up items -- everything else is up to you to figure out.  - Rudimentary crafting mechanics: the game boils down to picking up items from the floor (water bottles, wood, stone),  and clicking a button to create something. There's no sense of mining the environment or crafting the components,  beyond a cookie-cutter mechanism.  - Enemy model: the enemy is supposed to be a zombie, but it looks like a playable character, apart from making generic zombie sounds that get old really fast. More annoying than scary or interesting.  - Elementary AI: The enemies just follow you around, sometimes in a single-file, and get stuck in the environment.  - Fatigue system: You can run indefinitely, easily escaping the enemies until there are 300 of them after a few minutes.  - Technical issues: I've fallen through the border of the map, gone through objects, gotten hurt by enemies hitting me through walls. Could keep roaming around the map after dying. Haven't been able to put up a single wall (after creating a wall, the game only allows me to hit enemies with the wall).  - Overwhelming number of enemies: Enemies spawn all the time, leaving no room to enjoy the 'crafting experience'. I experience lag when I had 20 guys chasing me.  - Uninteresting map: The forest map is very small, has some houses, towers, trees, and collectibles. Nothing to harvest or explore.  - Costs $6.  Yes, all of that happened, as you can see from my video.  My playthrough consisted mostly of looking for bottles of watter, trying to figure out how to play the game, and running into issues.

I'll make this short and sweet.  Simply put, this is just another lazy cashgrab in a long line of lazy cashgrabs by this developer. The Lost Souls is a 'sequel' to White Mirror - except it's practically the same game with a different color palette. Same setting, same 'walk-up-to-statue-and-hit-keys-in-a-certain-order' puzzles, same underwater switch flipping, same monster, same, same, SAME.  Game is completable within 20 minutes, assuming it doesn't crash. (It's worth noting, the game didn't crash for me like it apparently did for others) The 'puzzles' are literally just typing words backwards in order to open locked doors. Unfulfilling, dull, senseless tripe. I'm sure the same will be said about the next game this developer uploads about 3 months from now, per his schedule.  In summary, terrible.

about 20 minutes of playtime and about 20 crashes...nuff said  its a 50/50 chance it will crash when you enter a new zone  its a 50/50 chance it will crash when you try to save game because you are afraid to that the game will crash and you will be in the previous zone  its a 50/50 chance it will crash when you try to load game, because you have crashed already but managed to save your game  10/10 would crash again

I don't know where this bloody influx of FPS Creator titles has come from and, frankly, it doesn't matter so long as we can assemble a team to burn it to the ground but, in the meantime, I sure hope you like your stages like an eight year old girl likes her bowling lanes: separated by GIANT CRASH BARRIERS.  Without fail, every area transition (of which there are only a merciful four) sent me hurtling back to the desktop with the gratingly familiar  'FPSC has stopped working'  taunt that is becoming far more familiar in my gaming pursuits than is acceptable. Occasionally you get a 'root system error' when you try to save as well which I guess is the closest thing this abomination is going to get to variety.   The Lost Souls  is atrociously written, horrendously translated and is honestly about throwing seven switches over fifteen minutes. Never buy it. Never play it. This would be considered an abuse of human rights by the government in a George Orwell novel.  Sheer garbage awaits your eyes below:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=obRqRrv6y9U

The game crashes a LOT. The graphics, except for the water, are sub-par and the story negates any fear of dying as you are already dead. That said it's slightly better than most low budget horrors that stumble onto steam, but this is not hard to achieve. The puzzles are hilariously simple and the game has NO options menu whatsoever. The occasional environment can look okay, but the textures elsewhere bring the game down.   Would only recommend if you're already dead IRL and need a reason to be glad about it.  For my full review with screenshots:  https://koolthingsforkoolkids.wordpress.com/2016/04/11/why-did-i-play-the-lost-souls/

This game kinda felt like a recycled White Mirror, which is another game this developer made. I'm very easily scared, but this game really didn't do it for me. I only played it for about 15 minutes so far, but its very remeniscent of the first game the developer made, which I thought was very dull. Still, its a VAST improvement over that game. I didn't experience any crashing, as other reviews point out, so I guess that's a plus. I wouldn't recommend this game, as it just lacks excitement for me.  Here is a few minutes of gameplay if you want to check it out:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cRqGsq_DyfI
The graphics are decent but it starts quite slow. i havnt gotten all the way through yet but its a very basic horror game.     http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=664197119

I was intrigued by the theme of this game and knew it had a significant number of bad reviews. I went ahead and got it anyway assuming other players were exaggerating. I found out that they were not exaggerating. It is a very short game which is generally empty in spite of the screenshots. The few monsters this game has are programmed in a way that they do not react to you, but merely follow a predefined path. The English is extremely bad and I would have expected the developer to let this game be reviewed by someone else more proficient in it. The story is only half a story. The puzzles are too trivial to even be in the game. You have to keep using the SHIFT button to move a little bit faster as without it, you would be bypassed by snails if they were in the game. The game has a replay value of 0. You can probably finish it in 20 - 50 minutes and will then never 'play' it again. As far as I am concerned most demos are more polished than this game. It really could have become something with a LOT of effort, but the developer apparently did not feel the need to do so and apparently chooses to keep selling empty games like this one in different formats. Unfortunate. The game does have a clever marketing strategy to draw players in, but that is all it has. In all fairness the game does have scary moments and they are not badly done, but they are very scarce and at some point you just know the full extent of what the game does and does not do and the surprises then end there. I just expected a lot more and a lot better.  In this case it was not a case of whether the game was good enough to play. No, it was a matter of whether the game was good enough to be in my library. I did not consider this game worthy to remain in my library and thus permanently removed it from my library.

This game can be completed in 20 minutes, but still got 3 hours left or more to completed the card drops. Sigh, it is so short.  As a horror walking simulator games, this game failed to scare me but give me a little frustating in chapter which player must collect 3 artifacts because of bug. Sometimes the artifacts doesn't spawn in the area, even reloading the area. I'd try to quit the games, load the chapter and got only 2 of artifacts. It means, I must save and quit the game. Come back and load the area, and the last artifact spawn. The 2nd bug is in the first chapter. If player go to left in the starting area, that can made the first puzzle can't be triggered and completed. So just quit & exit the game, start a new game and go foward in the starting area. These bugs is really annoying.  Sound effect in this game is dull, sometimes you can hear footsteps of the character but in the other chapter don't. However atmosphere is good. This game had a good graphic for a cheap budget games and has cinematic photography experience because of widescreen-like movie. It is not a good games nor bad games, but I can't recommended it because the games end too fast before I've starting to like it.

Awful, only 10 minutes in the game and 6 crashes before I gave up on this. Not worth it, even at 75 percent off. Here is my video on it if you are so curious  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vOMyzJVubWI

2/10  ... I have NO idea how, but this game managed to be worse than its predecessor. Which is quite surprising, given how the predecessor is by far not a good game.  The Lost Souls is the sequel to White Mirror. Supposedly, this time you're playing with a different character, since the one from the first game seemingly managed to escape. Once again, the one good thing about the game is that it looks good. Everything else is just as bad: barely any challenge, barely any story, barely any sense, barely... Anything.  The puzzles in this game managed to be even WORSE than they were before. How? In this case, you don't read documents that give you clues. No, the game just straight out describes the puzzle for you on the screen. I'm not kidding - in the first puzzle the game just shows a sequence of 6,5,4,3,2,1 and tells you to type it backwards, so you type 1,2,3,4,5,6 and the 'secret door' (which is NOT secret, it's LITERALLY out in the open, right behind you) opens. And every other puzzle in the game? Just type words. The game shows you backwards words like 'nepo pu' and you type 'openup'. THAT'S IT.  Oh and if you somehow mistype one of the solutions - if you accidentally type another letter (which isn't hard to do, considering you use WASD to walk), for instance? You're locked out of the puzzle. I'm not even kidding. You can't retry the puzzle. You have to load a previously saved game or restart everything.  And the ending?   THE MIRROR IS BROKEN AND YOU'RE STUCK IN HELL. THAT'S IT. I'M NOT EVEN JOKING. You have no idea why the character from the first game went to that house in the first place, then you're playing with this character who's actually in hell trying to find the so called 'mirror' only to find it's BROKEN and because of that, there's no escape. It's honestly one of the worst endings I've EVER seen in games.    And last, but not least - the game crashes. A lot. I had to retry chapter 3 three times because the game would just constantly crash.  Now, I really, REALLY want to support small devs. I know there's time and effort invested into doing games and it's often not easy doing it alone or with a small team. And these games (The Lost Souls, White Mirror, Verge: Lost Chapter, My Bones) are super cheap, so I wanted to say that at least they're worth the price for a short experience. But despite all of these, I cannot recommend these games (except for My Bones which I haven't played yet). They're just bad and it's not like there aren't any good options I could recommend instead - for instance, Black Rose, which is FREE.  If I could send a message to this dev, I'd suggest that he stop making all these incredibly short games and instead just invest time into making one that's longer and better. Create a story that makes sense and explains things. Make creative puzzles that make the player have to think for at least a short while. Create some level of challenge rather than just putting monsters that are incredibly easy to avoid. Don't overdo cheap jump scares and constant sounds/voices that come from nothing, create a creepy atmosphere instead (which isn't actually too hard - a dark atmosphere with just the occasional disturbing moment would be more than enough). Find someone to correct your english. Find people to test your game and make suggestions. And only THEN put it up for sale. Or, alternatively, do the same that was done with Black Rose - make a good game and release for free, then make an even better game and then sell that one.

Wow, this game is crap. Besides the crashing, it is incredibly short and dull. The puzzles are not puzzles and there really isn't a story. The graphics actually aren't too bad though. But not worth $1.99.

The developer describes this version as 'entirely kinetic,' which I can only suppose is an extremely vague way of saying there is no gameplay whatsoever - I mean there aren't even the choices you would normally encounter in a visual novel/adventure game. You're just in this to read the noninteractive story, which clocked in at just over 10 minutes for me, and is horrendously written and erratic, with an equally abrupt and nonsensical ending. The developer advertises a newly added save/load feature - for what, exactly? This is a ridiculous scam of a product, and I am thankful for Steam's refund policy.

I can't figure out why I wanted to try this. I was expecting something that wasn't so genuinely terrible as this perhaps? I feel like this is a cruddy source engine horror map converted to a visual novel. You can't save boring and inane writing by making it the focal point.
I liked The Last Dogma, I like the idea of making a visual novel game for the Genesis & wanted to play that; but this, this is at best a rather mediocre horror Tumblr.
